column2: Use of Function with Inconsistent Implementations
column4: The code uses a function that has inconsistent implementations across operating systems and versions. The use of inconsistent implementations can cause changes in behavior when the code is ported or built under a different environment than the programmer expects
column5: which can lead to security problems in some cases. The implementation of many functions varies by platform
column6: and at times
column7: even by different versions of the same platform. Implementation differences can include: Slight differences in the way parameters are interpreted leading to inconsistent results. Some implementations of the function carry significant security risks. The function might not be defined on all platforms. The function might change which return codes it can provide
column8: or change the meaning of its return codes.

column2: Undefined Behavior for Input to API
column4: The behavior of this function is undefined unless its control parameter is set to a specific value.

column2: Use of Obsolete Function
column4: The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions
column5: which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained. As programming languages evolve
column6: functions occasionally become obsolete due to: Advances in the language Improved understanding of how operations should be performed effectively and securely Changes in the conventions that govern certain operations Functions that are removed are usually replaced by newer counterparts that perform the same task in some different and hopefully improved way.

column2: Use of Low-Level Functionality
column4: The product uses low-level functionality that is explicitly prohibited by the framework or specification under which the product is supposed to operate. The use of low-level functionality can violate the specification in unexpected ways that effectively disable built-in protection mechanisms
column5: introduce exploitable inconsistencies
column6: or otherwise expose the functionality to attack.

column2: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function
column4: The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors
column5: but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted. This weakness can lead to a wide variety of resultant weaknesses
column6: depending on the behavior of the exposed method. It can apply to any number of technologies and approaches
column7: such as ActiveX controls
column10: and so on. The exposure can occur in a few different ways: The function/method was never intended to be exposed to outside actors. The function/method was only intended to be accessible to a limited set of actors
column11: such as Internet-based access from a single web site.

column2: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs
column4: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes output that is written to logs. This can allow an attacker to forge log entries or inject malicious content into logs. Log forging vulnerabilities occur when: Data enters an application from an untrusted source. The data is written to an application or system log file.

column2: Truncation of Security-relevant Information
column4: The product truncates the display
column5: recording
column6: or processing of security-relevant information in a way that can obscure the source or nature of an attack.

column2: Omission of Security-relevant Information
column4: The product does not record or display information that would be important for identifying the source or nature of an attack
column5: or determining if an action is safe.

column2: Obscured Security-relevant Information by Alternate Name
column4: The product records security-relevant information according to an alternate name of the affected entity
column5: instead of the canonical name.

column2: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File
column4: Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information. While logging all information may be helpful during development stages
column5: it is important that logging levels be set appropriately before a product ships so that sensitive user data and system information are not accidentally exposed to potential attackers. Different log files may be produced and stored for: Server log files (e.g. server.log). This can give information on whatever application left the file. Usually this can give full path names and system information
column6: and sometimes usernames and passwords. log files that are used for debugging

column2: Insufficient Logging
column4: When a security-critical event occurs
column5: the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it. When security-critical events are not logged properly
column6: such as a failed login attempt
column7: this can make malicious behavior more difficult to detect and may hinder forensic analysis after an attack succeeds. As organizations adopt cloud storage resources
column8: these technologies often require configuration changes to enable detailed logging information
column9: since detailed logging can incur additional costs. This could lead to telemetry gaps in critical audit logs. For example
column11: the default value for logging is disabled.

column2: Logging of Excessive Data
column4: The product logs too much information
column5: making log files hard to process and possibly hindering recovery efforts or forensic analysis after an attack. While logging is a good practice in general
column6: and very high levels of logging are appropriate for debugging stages of development
column7: too much logging in a production environment might hinder a system administrator's ability to detect anomalous conditions. This can provide cover for an attacker while attempting to penetrate a system
column8: clutter the audit trail for forensic analysis
column9: or make it more difficult to debug problems in a production environment.

column2: Authentication Bypass Using an Alternate Path or Channel
column4: A product requires authentication
column5: but the product has an alternate path or channel that does not require authentication.

column2: Authentication Bypass by Spoofing
column4: This attack-focused weakness is caused by incorrectly implemented authentication schemes that are subject to spoofing attacks.

column2: Authentication Bypass by Capture-replay
column4: A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes). Capture-replay attacks are common and can be difficult to defeat without cryptography. They are a subset of network injection attacks that rely on observing previously-sent valid commands
column5: then changing them slightly if necessary and resending the same commands to the server.

column2: Improper Certificate Validation
column4: The product does not validate
column5: or incorrectly validates
column6: a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious
column7: it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host
column8: or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

column2: Improper Following of a Certificate's Chain of Trust
column4: The product does not follow
column5: or incorrectly follows
column6: the chain of trust for a certificate back to a trusted root certificate
column7: resulting in incorrect trust of any resource that is associated with that certificate. If a system does not follow the chain of trust of a certificate to a root server
column8: the certificate loses all usefulness as a metric of trust. Essentially
column9: the trust gained from a certificate is derived from a chain of trust -- with a reputable trusted entity at the end of that list. The end user must trust that reputable source
column10: and this reputable source must vouch for the resource in question through the medium of the certificate. In some cases
column11: this trust traverses several entities who vouch for one another. The entity trusted by the end user is at one end of this trust chain
column12: while the certificate-wielding resource is at the other end of the chain. If the user receives a certificate at the end of one of these trust chains and then proceeds to check only that the first link in the chain
column13: no real trust has been derived
column14: since the entire chain must be traversed back to a trusted source to verify the certificate. There are several ways in which the chain of trust might be broken
column15: including but not limited to: Any certificate in the chain is self-signed
column16: unless it the root. Not every intermediate certificate is checked
column17: starting from the original certificate all the way up to the root certificate. An intermediate
column18: CA-signed certificate does not have the expected Basic Constraints or other important extensions. The root certificate has been compromised or authorized to the wrong party.

column2: Improper Check for Certificate Revocation
column4: The product does not check or incorrectly checks the revocation status of a certificate
column5: which may cause it to use a certificate that has been compromised. An improper check for certificate revocation is a far more serious flaw than related certificate failures. This is because the use of any revoked certificate is almost certainly malicious. The most common reason for certificate revocation is compromise of the system in question
column6: with the result that no legitimate servers will be using a revoked certificate
column7: unless they are sorely out of sync.

column2: Incorrect Implementation of Authentication Algorithm
column4: The requirements for the product dictate the use of an established authentication algorithm
column5: but the implementation of the algorithm is incorrect. This incorrect implementation may allow authentication to be bypassed.

column2: Missing Critical Step in Authentication
column4: The product implements an authentication technique
column5: but it skips a step that weakens the technique. Authentication techniques should follow the algorithms that define them exactly
column6: otherwise authentication can be bypassed or more easily subjected to brute force attacks.

column2: Authentication Bypass by Primary Weakness
column4: The authentication algorithm is sound
column5: but the implemented mechanism can be bypassed as the result of a separate weakness that is primary to the authentication error.

column2: Missing Authentication for Critical Function
column4: The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources. As data is migrated to the cloud
column5: if access does not require authentication
column6: it can be easier for attackers to access the data from anywhere on the Internet.

column2: Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts
column4: The product does not implement sufficient measures to prevent multiple failed authentication attempts within a short time frame
column5: making it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

column2: Use of Single-factor Authentication
column4: The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication
column5: it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak
column6: reused
column7: and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes
column8: a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason
column9: if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use
column10: they should be implemented and required.

column2: Use of Password System for Primary Authentication
column4: The use of password systems as the primary means of authentication may be subject to several flaws or shortcomings
column5: each reducing the effectiveness of the mechanism.

column2: Key Exchange without Entity Authentication
column4: The product performs a key exchange with an actor without verifying the identity of that actor. Performing a key exchange will preserve the integrity of the information sent between two entities
column5: but this will not guarantee that the entities are who they claim they are. This may enable an attacker to impersonate an actor by modifying traffic between the two entities. Typically
column6: this involves a victim client that contacts a malicious server that is impersonating a trusted server. If the client skips authentication or ignores an authentication failure
column7: the malicious server may request authentication information from the user. The malicious server can then use this authentication information to log in to the trusted server using the victim's credentials
column8: sniff traffic between the victim and trusted server

column2: Use of Client-Side Authentication
column4: A client/server product performs authentication within client code but not in server code
column5: allowing server-side authentication to be bypassed via a modified client that omits the authentication check. Client-side authentication is extremely weak and may be breached easily. Any attacker may read the source code and reverse-engineer the authentication mechanism to access parts of the application which would otherwise be protected.

column2: Overly Restrictive Account Lockout Mechanism
column4: The product contains an account lockout protection mechanism
column5: but the mechanism is too restrictive and can be triggered too easily
column6: which allows attackers to deny service to legitimate users by causing their accounts to be locked out. Account lockout is a security feature often present in applications as a countermeasure to the brute force attack on the password based authentication mechanism of the system. After a certain number of failed login attempts
column7: the users' account may be disabled for a certain period of time or until it is unlocked by an administrator. Other security events may also possibly trigger account lockout. However
column8: an attacker may use this very security feature to deny service to legitimate system users. It is therefore important to ensure that the account lockout security mechanism is not overly restrictive.

column2: Guessable CAPTCHA
column4: The product uses a CAPTCHA challenge
column5: but the challenge can be guessed or automatically recognized by a non-human actor. An automated attacker could bypass the intended protection of the CAPTCHA challenge and perform actions at a higher frequency than humanly possible
column6: such as launching spam attacks. There can be several different causes of a guessable CAPTCHA: An audio or visual image that does not have sufficient distortion from the unobfuscated source image. A question is generated with a format that can be automatically recognized
column7: such as a math question. A question for which the number of possible answers is limited
column8: such as birth years or favorite sports teams. A general-knowledge or trivia question for which the answer can be accessed using a data base
column9: such as country capitals or popular entertainers. Other data associated with the CAPTCHA may provide hints about its contents
column10: such as an image whose filename contains the word that is used in the CAPTCHA.

column2: Use of Password Hash Instead of Password for Authentication
column4: The product records password hashes in a data store
column5: receives a hash of a password from a client
column6: and compares the supplied hash to the hash obtained from the data store. Some authentication mechanisms rely on the client to generate the hash for a password
column7: possibly to reduce load on the server or avoid sending the password across the network. However
column8: when the client is used to generate the hash
column9: an attacker can bypass the authentication by obtaining a copy of the hash
column10: e.g. by using SQL injection to compromise a database of authentication credentials
column11: or by exploiting an information exposure. The attacker could then use a modified client to replay the stolen hash without having knowledge of the original password. As a result
column12: the server-side comparison against a client-side hash does not provide any more security than the use of passwords without hashing.
column14: Product performs authentication with user-supplied password hashes that can be obtained from a separate SQL injection vulnerability (CVE-2009-1282).

column2: Direct Request ('Forced Browsing')
column4: The web application does not adequately enforce appropriate authorization on all restricted URLs
column5: scripts
column6: or files. Web applications susceptible to direct request attacks often make the false assumption that such resources can only be reached through a given navigation path and so only apply authorization at certain points in the path.

column2: Incorrect Behavior Order: Authorization Before Parsing and Canonicalization
column4: If a web server does not fully parse requested URLs before it examines them for authorization
column5: it may be possible for an attacker to bypass authorization protection. For instance
column6: the character strings /./ and / both mean current directory. If /SomeDirectory is a protected directory and an attacker requests /./SomeDirectory
column7: the attacker may be able to gain access to the resource if /./ is not converted to / before the authorization check is performed.

column2: Improper Authorization of Index Containing Sensitive Information
column4: The product creates a search index of private or sensitive documents
column5: but it does not properly limit index access to actors who are authorized to see the original information. Web sites and other document repositories may apply an indexing routine against a group of private documents to facilitate search. If the index's results are available to parties who do not have access to the documents being indexed
column6: then attackers could obtain portions of the documents by conducting targeted searches and reading the results. The risk is especially dangerous if search results include surrounding text that was not part of the search query. This issue can appear in search engines that are not configured (or implemented) to ignore critical files that should remain hidden; even without permissions to download these files directly
column7: the remote user could read them.

column2: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key
column4: The system's authorization functionality does not prevent one user from gaining access to another user's data or record by modifying the key value identifying the data. Retrieval of a user record occurs in the system based on some key value that is under user control. The key would typically identify a user-related record stored in the system and would be used to lookup that record for presentation to the user. It is likely that an attacker would have to be an authenticated user in the system. However
column5: the authorization process would not properly check the data access operation to ensure that the authenticated user performing the operation has sufficient entitlements to perform the requested data access
column6: hence bypassing any other authorization checks present in the system. For example
column7: attackers can look at places where user specific data is retrieved (e.g. search screens) and determine whether the key for the item being looked up is controllable externally. The key may be a hidden field in the HTML form field
column8: might be passed as a URL parameter or as an unencrypted cookie variable
column9: then in each of these cases it will be possible to tamper with the key value. One manifestation of this weakness is when a system uses sequential or otherwise easily-guessable session IDs that would allow one user to easily switch to another user's session and read/modify their data.

column2: Placement of User into Incorrect Group
column4: The product or the administrator places a user into an incorrect group. If the incorrect group has more access or privileges than the intended group
column5: the user might be able to bypass intended security policy to access unexpected resources or perform unexpected actions. The access-control system might not be able to detect malicious usage of this group membership.

column2: Insufficient Granularity of Access Control
column4: The product implements access controls via a policy or other feature with the intention to disable or restrict accesses (reads and/or writes) to assets in a system from untrusted agents. However
column5: implemented access controls lack required granularity
column6: which renders the control policy too broad because it allows accesses from unauthorized agents to the security-sensitive assets. Integrated circuits and hardware engines can expose accesses to assets (device configuration
column7: keys
column8: etc.) to trusted firmware or a software module (commonly set by BIOS/bootloader). This access is typically access-controlled. Upon a power reset
column9: the hardware or system usually starts with default values in registers
column10: and the trusted firmware (Boot firmware) configures the necessary access-control protection. A common weakness that can exist in such protection schemes is that access controls or policies are not granular enough. This condition allows agents beyond trusted agents to access assets and could lead to a loss of functionality or the ability to set up the device securely. This further results in security risks from leaked
column12: key material to modification of device configuration.

column2: Missing Default Case in Multiple Condition Expression
column4: The code does not have a default case in an expression with multiple conditions
column5: such as a switch statement. If a multiple-condition expression (such as a switch in C) omits the default case but does not consider or handle all possible values that could occur
column6: then this might lead to complex logical errors and resultant weaknesses. Because of this
column7: further decisions are made based on poor information
column8: and cascading failure results. This cascading failure may result in any number of security issues
column9: and constitutes a significant failure in the system.

column2: Reliance on Package-level Scope
column4: Java packages are not inherently closed; therefore
column5: relying on them for code security is not a good practice. The purpose of package scope is to prevent accidental access by other parts of a program. This is an ease-of-software-development feature but not a security feature.

column2: Active Debug Code
column4: The product is deployed to unauthorized actors with debugging code still enabled or active
column5: which can create unintended entry points or expose sensitive information. A common development practice is to add "back door" code specifically designed for debugging or testing purposes that is not intended to be shipped or deployed with the product. These back door entry points create security risks because they are not considered during design or testing and fall outside of the expected operating conditions of the product.

column2: Suspicious Comment
column4: The code contains comments that suggest the presence of bugs
column5: incomplete functionality
column6: or weaknesses. Many suspicious comments
column7: such as BUG
column13: in the code indicate missing security functionality and checking. Others indicate code problems that programmers should fix

column2: Use of Hard-coded
column5: The product uses hard-coded constants instead of symbolic names for security-critical values
column6: which increases the likelihood of mistakes during code maintenance or security policy change. If the developer does not find all occurrences of the hard-coded constants
column7: an incorrect policy decision may be made if one of the constants is not changed. Making changes to these values will require code changes that may be difficult or impossible once the system is released to the field. In addition
column8: these hard-coded values may become available to attackers if the code is ever disclosed.

column2: Dead Code
column4: The product contains dead code
column5: which can never be executed. Dead code is code that can never be executed in a running program. The surrounding code makes it impossible for a section of code to ever be executed.

column2: Assignment to Variable without Use
column4: The variable's value is assigned but never used
column5: making it a dead store. After the assignment
column6: the variable is either assigned another value or goes out of scope. It is likely that the variable is simply vestigial
column7: but it is also possible that the unused variable points out a bug.

column2: Object Model Violation: Just One of Equals and Hashcode Defined
column4: The product does not maintain equal hashcodes for equal objects. Java objects are expected to obey a number of invariants related to equality. One of these invariants is that equal objects must have equal hashcodes. In other words
column5: if a.equals(b) == true then a.hashCode() == b.hashCode().

column2: Explicit Call to Finalize()
column4: The product makes an explicit call to the finalize() method from outside the finalizer. While the Java Language Specification allows an object's finalize() method to be called from outside the finalizer
column5: doing so is usually a bad idea. For example
column6: calling finalize() explicitly means that finalize() will be called more than once: the first time will be the explicit call and the last time will be the call that is made after the object is garbage collected.

column2: Multiple Binds to the Same Port
column4: When multiple sockets are allowed to bind to the same port
column5: other services on that port may be stolen or spoofed. On most systems
column6: a combination of setting the SO_REUSEADDR socket option
column7: and a call to bind() allows any process to bind to a port to which a previous process has bound with INADDR_ANY. This allows a user to bind to the specific address of a server bound to INADDR_ANY on an unprivileged port
column8: and steal its UDP packets/TCP connection.

column2: Function Call with Incorrectly Specified Arguments
column4: The product calls a function
column5: procedure
column6: or routine with arguments that are not correctly specified
column7: leading to always-incorrect behavior and resultant weaknesses. There are multiple ways in which this weakness can be introduced
column8: including: the wrong variable or reference; an incorrect number of arguments; incorrect order of arguments; wrong type of arguments; or wrong value.

column2: Use of Multiple Resources with Duplicate Identifier
column4: The product uses multiple resources that can have the same identifier
column5: in a context in which unique identifiers are required. If the product assumes that each resource has a unique identifier
column6: the product could operate on the wrong resource if attackers can cause multiple resources to be associated with the same identifier.

column2: Use of Redundant Code
column4: The product has multiple functions
column5: methods
column6: procedures
column7: macros
column8: etc. that contain the same code. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column9: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. For example
column10: if there are two copies of the same code
column11: the programmer might fix a weakness in one copy while forgetting to fix the same weakness in another copy.

column2: Data Element Aggregating an Excessively Large Number of Non-Primitive Elements
column4: The product uses a data element that has an excessively large number of sub-elements with non-primitive data types such as structures or aggregated objects. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column5: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability. While the interpretation of "excessively large" may vary for each product or developer
column6: CISQ recommends a default of 5 sub-elements.

column2: Architecture with Number of Horizontal Layers Outside of Expected Range
column4: The product's architecture contains too many - or too few - horizontal layers. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities. While the interpretation of "expected range" may vary for each product or developer
column6: CISQ recommends a default minimum of 4 layers and maximum of 8 layers.

column4: A parent class has a virtual destructor method
column5: but the parent has a child class that does not have a virtual destructor. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably
column6: since the child might not perform essential destruction operations. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column7: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability

column2: Creation of Immutable Text Using String Concatenation
column4: The product creates an immutable text string using string concatenation operations. When building a string via a looping feature (e.g.
column5: a FOR or WHILE loop)
column6: the use of += to append to the existing string will result in the creation of a new object with each iteration. This programming pattern can be inefficient in comparison with use of text buffer data elements. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column7: then this could be influenced to create performance problem.

column6: CISQ recommends a default of 5 referenced objects. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product

column6: CISQ recommends a default of 1 million rows for a "large" data table
column7: a default minimum of 5 joins
column8: and a default minimum of 3 sub-queries.

column2: Excessive Platform Resource Consumption within a Loop
column4: The product has a loop body or loop condition that contains a control element that directly or indirectly consumes platform resources
column5: e.g. messaging
column6: sessions
column7: locks
column8: or file descriptors. This issue can make the product perform more slowly. If an attacker can influence the number of iterations in the loop
column9: then this performance problem might allow a denial of service by consuming more platform resources than intended.

column2: Creation of Class Instance within a Static Code Block
column4: A static code block creates an instance of a class. This issue can make the product perform more slowly by performing initialization before it is needed. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker

column4: The product uses deployed components from application servers

column4: The source code contains a block that does not contain any code

column6: the block is empty. Empty code blocks can occur in the bodies of conditionals

column5: i.e.

column4: A function or method contains too many operations that utilize a data manager or file resource. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product

There might be no throttling done on the rate of password resets so that a legitimate user can be denied service by an attacker if an attacker tries to recover their password in a rapid succession. The system may send the original password to the user rather than generating a new temporary password. In summary

column2: Covert Storage Channel
column4: A covert storage channel transfers information through the setting of bits by one program and the reading of those bits by another. What distinguishes this case from that of ordinary operation is that the bits are used to convey encoded information. Covert storage channels occur when out-of-band data is stored in messages for the purpose of memory reuse. Covert channels are frequently classified as either storage or timing channels. Examples would include using a file intended to hold only audit information to convey user passwords--using the name of a file or perhaps status bits associated with it that can be read by all users to signal the contents of the file. Steganography
column5: concealing information in such a manner that no one but the intended recipient knows of the existence of the message
column6: is a good example of a covert storage channel.

column5: i.e.
column6: it has a large number of parent classes. This issue makes it more difficult to understand and maintain the product
column7: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities. While the interpretation of "large number of parent classes" may vary for each product or developer
column8: CISQ recommends a default maximum of 7 parent classes.

column2: Unconditional Control Flow Transfer outside of Switch Block
column4: The product performs unconditional control transfer (such as a "goto") in code outside of a branching structure such as a switch block. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Source Code File with Excessive Number of Lines of Code
column4: A source code file has too many lines of code. This issue makes it more difficult to understand and/or maintain the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities. While the interpretation of "too many lines of code" may vary for each product or developer
column6: CISQ recommends a default threshold value of 1000.

column2: Class with Excessive Number of Child Classes
column4: A class contains an unnecessarily large number of children. This issue makes it more difficult to understand and maintain the software
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities. While the interpretation of "large number of children" may vary for each product or developer
column6: CISQ recommends a default maximum of 10 child classes.

column2: Loop Condition Value Update within the Loop
column4: The product uses a loop with a control flow condition based on a value that is updated within the body of the loop. This issue makes it more difficult to understand and/or maintain the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Excessive Use of Unconditional Branching
column4: The code uses too many unconditional branches (such as "goto"). This issue makes it more difficult to understand and/or maintain the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Excessive McCabe Cyclomatic Complexity
column4: The code contains McCabe cyclomatic complexity that exceeds a desirable maximum. This issue makes it more difficult to understand and/or maintain the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Excessive Halstead Complexity
column4: The code is structured in a way that a Halstead complexity measure exceeds a desirable maximum. A variety of Halstead complexity measures exist
column5: such as program vocabulary size or volume. This issue makes it more difficult to understand and/or maintain the product
column6: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Excessive Use of Self-Modifying Code
column4: The product uses too much self-modifying code. This issue makes it more difficult to understand or maintain the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Excessively Deep Nesting
column4: The code contains a callable or other code grouping in which the nesting / branching is too deep. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Excessive Attack Surface
column4: The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum. Originating from software security
column5: an "attack surface" measure typically reflects the number of input points and output points that can be utilized by an untrusted party
column6: i.e. a potential attacker. A larger attack surface provides more places to attack
column7: and more opportunities for developers to introduce weaknesses. In some cases
column8: this measure may reflect other aspects of quality besides security; e.g.
column9: a product with many inputs and outputs may require a large number of tests in order to improve code coverage.

column2: Race Condition Enabling Link Following
column4: The product checks the status of a file or directory before accessing it
column5: which produces a race condition in which the file can be replaced with a link before the access is performed
column6: causing the product to access the wrong file. While developers might expect that there is a very narrow time window between the time of check and time of use
column7: there is still a race condition. An attacker could cause the product to slow down (e.g. with memory consumption)
column8: causing the time window to become larger. Alternately
column10: the attacker could win the race by performing a large number of attacks.

column2: Race Condition within a Thread
column4: If two threads of execution use a resource simultaneously
column5: there exists the possibility that resources may be used while invalid
column6: in turn making the state of execution undefined.

column2: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition
column4: The product checks the state of a resource before using that resource
column5: but the resource's state can change between the check and the use in a way that invalidates the results of the check. This can cause the product to perform invalid actions when the resource is in an unexpected state. This weakness can be security-relevant when an attacker can influence the state of the resource between check and use. This can happen with shared resources such as files
column6: memory
column7: or even variables in multithreaded programs.

column2: Context Switching Race Condition
column4: A product performs a series of non-atomic actions to switch between contexts that cross privilege or other security boundaries
column5: but a race condition allows an attacker to modify or misrepresent the product's behavior during the switch. This is commonly seen in web browser vulnerabilities in which the attacker can perform certain actions while the browser is transitioning from a trusted to an untrusted domain
column6: or vice versa
column7: and the browser performs the actions on one domain using the trust level and resources of the other domain.

column2: Symbolic Name not Mapping to Correct Object
column4: A constant symbolic reference to an object is used
column5: even though the reference can resolve to a different object over time.

column2: Race Condition During Access to Alternate Channel
column4: The product opens an alternate channel to communicate with an authorized user
column5: but the channel is accessible to other actors. This creates a race condition that allows an attacker to access the channel before the authorized user does.

column2: Unsynchronized Access to Shared Data in a Multithreaded Context
column4: The product does not properly synchronize shared data
column5: such as static variables across threads
column6: which can lead to undefined behavior and unpredictable data changes. Within servlets
column7: shared static variables are not protected from concurrent access
column8: but servlets are multithreaded. This is a typical programming mistake in J2EE applications
column9: since the multithreading is handled by the framework. When a shared variable can be influenced by an attacker
column10: one thread could wind up modifying the variable to contain data that is not valid for a different thread that is also using the data within the variable. Note that this weakness is not unique to servlets.

column2: Empty Synchronized Block
column4: The product contains an empty synchronized block. An empty synchronized block does not actually accomplish any synchronization and may indicate a troubled section of code. An empty synchronized block can occur because code no longer needed within the synchronized block is commented out without removing the synchronized block.

column2: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context
column4: The product calls a non-reentrant function in a concurrent context in which a competing code sequence (e.g. thread or signal handler) may have an opportunity to call the same function or otherwise influence its state.

column2: Missing Synchronization
column4: The product utilizes a shared resource in a concurrent manner but does not attempt to synchronize access to the resource. If access to a shared resource is not synchronized
column5: then the resource may not be in a state that is expected by the product. This might lead to unexpected or insecure behaviors
column6: especially if an attacker can influence the shared resource.

column2: Incorrect Synchronization
column4: The product utilizes a shared resource in a concurrent manner
column5: but it does not correctly synchronize access to the resource. If access to a shared resource is not correctly synchronized
column6: then the resource may not be in a state that is expected by the product. This might lead to unexpected or insecure behaviors
column7: especially if an attacker can influence the shared resource.

column2: Invokable Control Element in Multi-Thread Context with non-Final Static Storable or Member Element
column4: The code contains a function or method that operates in a multi-threaded environment but owns an unsafe non-final static storable or member data element. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column5: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.

column2: Synchronous Access of Remote Resource without Timeout
column4: The code has a synchronous call to a remote resource
column5: but there is no timeout for the call
column6: or the timeout is set to infinite. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably
column7: since an outage for the remote resource can cause the product to hang. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column8: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.

column2: Plaintext Storage of a Password
column4: Storing a password in plaintext may result in a system compromise. Password management issues occur when a password is stored in plaintext in an application's properties
column5: configuration file
column6: or memory. Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file allows anyone who can read the file access to the password-protected resource. In some contexts
column7: even storage of a plaintext password in memory is considered a security risk if the password is not cleared immediately after it is used.

column2: Storing Passwords in a Recoverable Format
column4: The storage of passwords in a recoverable format makes them subject to password reuse attacks by malicious users. In fact
column5: it should be noted that recoverable encrypted passwords provide no significant benefit over plaintext passwords since they are subject not only to reuse by malicious attackers but also by malicious insiders. If a system administrator can recover a password directly
column6: or use a brute force search on the available information
column7: the administrator can use the password on other accounts.

column2: Password in Configuration File
column4: The product stores a password in a configuration file that might be accessible to actors who do not know the password. This can result in compromise of the system for which the password is used. An attacker could gain access to this file and learn the stored password or worse yet
column5: change the password to one of their choosing.

column2: Weak Encoding for Password
column4: Obscuring a password with a trivial encoding does not protect the password. Password management issues occur when a password is stored in plaintext in an application's properties or configuration file. A programmer can attempt to remedy the password management problem by obscuring the password with an encoding function
column5: such as base 64 encoding
column6: but this effort does not adequately protect the password.

column2: Not Using Password Aging
column4: The product does not have a mechanism in place for managing password aging. Password aging (or password rotation) is a policy that forces users to change their passwords after a defined time period passes
column5: such as every 30 or 90 days. Without mechanisms such as aging
column6: users might not change their passwords in a timely manner. Note that while password aging was once considered an important security feature
column7: it has since fallen out of favor by many
column8: because it is not as effective against modern threats compared to other mechanisms such as slow hashes. In addition
column9: forcing frequent changes can unintentionally encourage users to select less-secure passwords. However
column10: password aging is still in use due to factors such as compliance requirements
column12: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS).

column2: Password Aging with Long Expiration
column4: The product supports password aging
column5: but the expiration period is too long. Password aging (or password rotation) is a policy that forces users to change their passwords after a defined time period passes
column6: such as every 30 or 90 days. A long expiration provides more time for attackers to conduct password cracking before users are forced to change to a new password. Note that while password aging was once considered an important security feature
column7: it has since fallen out of favor by many
column8: because it is not as effective against modern threats compared to other mechanisms such as slow hashes. In addition
column9: forcing frequent changes can unintentionally encourage users to select less-secure passwords. However
column10: password aging is still in use due to factors such as compliance requirements
column12: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS).

column2: Use of a Key Past its Expiration Date
column4: The product uses a cryptographic key or password past its expiration date
column5: which diminishes its safety significantly by increasing the timing window for cracking attacks against that key. While the expiration of keys does not necessarily ensure that they are compromised
column6: it is a significant concern that keys which remain in use for prolonged periods of time have a decreasing probability of integrity. For this reason
column7: it is important to replace keys within a period of time proportional to their strength.

column2: Weak Password Requirements
column4: The product does not require that users should have strong passwords
column5: which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

column2: Unprotected Transport of Credentials
column4: Login pages do not use adequate measures to protect the user name and password while they are in transit from the client to the server.

column2: Missing Password Field Masking
column4: The product does not mask passwords during entry
column5: increasing the potential for attackers to observe and capture passwords.

column2: Unverified Password Change
column4: When setting a new password for a user
column5: the product does not require knowledge of the original password
column6: or using another form of authentication. This could be used by an attacker to change passwords for another user
column7: thus gaining the privileges associated with that user.

column2: Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password
column4: The product contains a mechanism for users to recover or change their passwords without knowing the original password
column5: but the mechanism is weak. It is common for an application to have a mechanism that provides a means for a user to gain access to their account in the event they forget their password. Very often the password recovery mechanism is weak
column6: which has the effect of making it more likely that it would be possible for a person other than the legitimate system user to gain access to that user's account. Weak password recovery schemes completely undermine a strong password authentication scheme. This weakness may be that the security question is too easy to guess or find an answer to (e.g. because the question is too common
column7: or the answers can be found using social media). Or there might be an implementation weakness in the password recovery mechanism code that may for instance trick the system into e-mailing the new password to an e-mail account other than that of the user. There might be no throttling done on the rate of password resets so that a legitimate user can be denied service by an attacker if an attacker tries to recover their password in a rapid succession. The system may send the original password to the user rather than generating a new temporary password. In summary
column9: if not carefully designed and implemented can often become the system's weakest link that can be misused in a way that would allow an attacker to gain unauthorized access to the system.

column2: Use of Hard-coded Credentials
column4: The product contains hard-coded credentials
column5: such as a password or cryptographic key
column6: which it uses for its own inbound authentication
column7: outbound communication to external components
column8: or encryption of internal data. Hard-coded credentials typically create a significant hole that allows an attacker to bypass the authentication that has been configured by the product administrator. This hole might be difficult for the system administrator to detect. Even if detected
column9: it can be difficult to fix
column10: so the administrator may be forced into disabling the product entirely. There are two main variations: Inbound: the product contains an authentication mechanism that checks the input credentials against a hard-coded set of credentials. Outbound: the product connects to another system or component
column11: and it contains hard-coded credentials for connecting to that component. In the Inbound variant
column12: a default administration account is created
column13: and a simple password is hard-coded into the product and associated with that account. This hard-coded password is the same for each installation of the product
column14: and it usually cannot be changed or disabled by system administrators without manually modifying the program
column15: or otherwise patching the product. If the password is ever discovered or published (a common occurrence on the Internet)
column16: then anybody with knowledge of this password can access the product. Finally
column17: since all installations of the product will have the same password
column19: this enables massive attacks such as worms to take place. The Outbound variant applies to front-end systems that authenticate with a back-end service. The back-end service may require a fixed password which can be easily discovered. The programmer may simply hard-code those back-end credentials into the front-end product. Any user of that program may be able to extract the password. Client-side systems with hard-coded passwords pose even more of a threat
column20: since the extraction of a password from a binary is usually very simple.

column2: Use of Weak Hash

column5: find another input that can produce the same hash (2nd preimage attack)

A hash function is defined as an algorithm that maps arbitrarily sized data into a fixed-sized digest (output) such that the following properties hold: 1. The algorithm is not invertible (also called "one-way" or "not reversible") 2. The algorithm is deterministic; the same input produces the same digest every time Building on this definition
column7: a cryptographic hash function must also ensure that a malicious actor cannot leverage the hash function to have a reasonable chance of success at determining any of the following: 1. the original input (preimage attack)

column9: given the original input 3. a set of two or more inputs that evaluate to the same digest (birthday attack)
column10: given the actor can arbitrarily choose the inputs to be hashed and can do so a reasonable amount of times What is regarded as "reasonable" varies by context and threat model

column14: attempting half of all possible combinations). Note that some attacks might be more efficient than brute force but are still not regarded as achievable in the real world. column2: Use of a Cryptographic Primitive with a Risky Implementation
column4: To fulfill the need for a cryptographic primitive
column5: the product implements a cryptographic algorithm using a non-standard
column6: unproven
column7: or disallowed/non-compliant cryptographic implementation. Cryptographic protocols and systems depend on cryptographic primitives (and associated algorithms) as their basic building blocks. Some common examples of primitives are digital signatures
column11: the notion of "primitive" can vary depending on point of view. See "Terminology Notes" for further explanation of some concepts. Cryptographic primitives are defined to accomplish one very specific task in a precisely defined and mathematically reliable fashion. For example
column12: suppose that for a specific cryptographic primitive (such as an encryption routine)
column13: the consensus is that the primitive can only be broken after trying out N different inputs (where the larger the value of N
column14: the stronger the cryptography). For an encryption scheme like AES-256
column15: one would expect N to be so large as to be infeasible to execute in a reasonable amount of time. If a vulnerability is ever found that shows that one can break a cryptographic primitive in significantly less than the expected number of attempts
column16: then that primitive is considered weakened (or sometimes in extreme cases
column17: colloquially it is "broken"). As a result
column18: anything using this cryptographic primitive would now be considered insecure or risky. Thus
column19: even breaking or weakening a seemingly small cryptographic primitive has the potential to render the whole system vulnerable
column20: due to its reliance on the primitive. A historical example can be found in TLS when using DES. One would colloquially call DES the cryptographic primitive for transport encryption in this version of TLS. In the past
column22: because no weaknesses were found in it; importantly
column23: DES has a key length of 56 bits. Trying N=2^56 keys was considered impractical for most actors. Unfortunately
column24: attacking a system with 56-bit keys is now practical via brute force
column25: which makes defeating DES encryption practical. It is now practical for an adversary to read any information sent under this version of TLS and use this information to attack the system. As a result
column26: it can be claimed that this use of TLS is weak
column27: and that any system depending on TLS with DES could potentially render the entire system vulnerable to attack. Cryptographic primitives and associated algorithms are only considered safe after extensive research and review from experienced cryptographers from academia
column29: and government entities looking for any possible flaws. Furthermore

column33: resulting in the exposure of sensitive information and other consequences. This weakness is even more difficult to manage for hardware-implemented deployment of cryptographic algorithms. First
