column2: Key Exchange without Entity Authentication
column4: The product performs a key exchange with an actor without verifying the identity of that actor. Performing a key exchange will preserve the integrity of the information sent between two entities
column5: but this will not guarantee that the entities are who they claim they are. This may enable an attacker to impersonate an actor by modifying traffic between the two entities. Typically
column6: this involves a victim client that contacts a malicious server that is impersonating a trusted server. If the client skips authentication or ignores an authentication failure
column7: the malicious server may request authentication information from the user. The malicious server can then use this authentication information to log in to the trusted server using the victim's credentials
column8: sniff traffic between the victim and trusted server

column2: Origin Validation Error
column4: The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

column2: Improper Verification of Cryptographic Signature
column4: The product does not verify
column5: or incorrectly verifies
column6: the cryptographic signature for data.

column2: Use of Less Trusted Source
column4: The product has two different sources of the same data or information
column5: but it uses the source that has less support for verification
column6: is less trusted
column7: or is less resistant to attack.

column2: Acceptance of Extraneous Untrusted Data With Trusted Data
column4: The product
column5: when processing trusted data
column6: accepts any untrusted data that is also included with the trusted data
column7: treating the untrusted data as if it were trusted.

column2: Insufficient Type Distinction
column4: The product does not properly distinguish between different types of elements in a way that leads to insecure behavior.

column2: Missing Support for Integrity Check
column4: The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission
column5: such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol
column6: there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications
column7: the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum
column8: since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages

column2: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value
column4: The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or "checksums" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission. Improper validation of checksums before use results in an unnecessary risk that can easily be mitigated. The protocol specification describes the algorithm used for calculating the checksum. It is then a simple matter of implementing the calculation and verifying that the calculated checksum and the received checksum match. Improper verification of the calculated checksum and the received checksum can lead to far greater consequences.

column2: Download of Code Without Integrity Check
column4: The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server
column5: performing DNS spoofing
column6: or modifying the code in transit.

column2: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking
column4: The product relies on the existence or values of cookies when performing security-critical operations
column5: but it does not properly ensure that the setting is valid for the associated user. Attackers can easily modify cookies
column6: within the browser or by implementing the client-side code outside of the browser. Reliance on cookies without detailed validation and integrity checking can allow attackers to bypass authentication
column7: conduct injection attacks such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting
column8: or otherwise modify inputs in unexpected ways.

column2: Reliance on Obfuscation or Encryption of Security-Relevant Inputs without Integrity Checking
column4: The product uses obfuscation or encryption of inputs that should not be mutable by an external actor
column5: but the product does not use integrity checks to detect if those inputs have been modified. When an application relies on obfuscation or incorrectly applied / weak encryption to protect client-controllable tokens or parameters
column6: that may have an effect on the user state
column7: system state
column8: or some decision made on the server. Without protecting the tokens/parameters for integrity
column9: the application is vulnerable to an attack where an adversary traverses the space of possible values of the said token/parameter in order to attempt to gain an advantage. The goal of the attacker is to find another admissible value that will somehow elevate their privileges in the system
column10: disclose information or change the behavior of the system in some way beneficial to the attacker. If the application does not protect these critical tokens/parameters for integrity
column11: it will not be able to determine that these values have been tampered with. Measures that are used to protect data for confidentiality should not be relied upon to provide the integrity service.

column2: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere
column4: The product imports
column5: requires
column6: or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere. When including third-party functionality
column7: such as a web widget
column10: the product must effectively trust that functionality. Without sufficient protection mechanisms
column11: the functionality could be malicious in nature (either by coming from an untrusted source
column13: or being modified in transit from a trusted source). The functionality might also contain its own weaknesses
column14: or grant access to additional functionality and state information that should be kept private to the base system
column17: or the DOM of a web application. This might lead to many different consequences depending on the included functionality
column18: but some examples include injection of malware
column19: information exposure by granting excessive privileges or permissions to the untrusted functionality

column2: Improper Enforcement of Message Integrity During Transmission in a Communication Channel
column4: The product establishes a communication channel with an endpoint and receives a message from that endpoint
column5: but it does not sufficiently ensure that the message was not modified during transmission. Attackers might be able to modify the message and spoof the endpoint by interfering with the data as it crosses the network or by redirecting the connection to a system under their control.

column2: Improper Handling of Length Parameter Inconsistency
column4: The product parses a formatted message or structure
column5: but it does not handle or incorrectly handles a length field that is inconsistent with the actual length of the associated data. If an attacker can manipulate the length parameter associated with an input such that it is inconsistent with the actual length of the input
column6: this can be leveraged to cause the target application to behave in unexpected
column7: and possibly
column8: malicious ways. One of the possible motives for doing so is to pass in arbitrarily large input to the application. Another possible motivation is the modification of application state by including invalid data for subsequent properties of the application. Such weaknesses commonly lead to attacks such as buffer overflows and execution of arbitrary code.

column2: Improper Handling of Missing Special Element
column4: The product receives input from an upstream component
column5: but it does not handle or incorrectly handles when an expected special element is missing.

column2: Improper Handling of Additional Special Element
column4: The product receives input from an upstream component
column5: but it does not handle or incorrectly handles when an additional unexpected special element is provided.

column2: Improper Handling of Inconsistent Special Elements
column4: The product does not properly handle input in which an inconsistency exists between two or more special characters or reserved words. An example of this problem would be if paired characters appear in the wrong order
column5: or if the special characters are not properly nested.

column2: Improper Handling of Case Sensitivity
column4: The product does not properly account for differences in case sensitivity when accessing or determining the properties of a resource
column5: leading to inconsistent results. Improperly handled case sensitive data can lead to several possible consequences
column6: including: case-insensitive passwords reducing the size of the key space
column7: making brute force attacks easier bypassing filters or access controls using alternate names multiple interpretation errors using alternate names.

column2: Collapse of Data into Unsafe Value
column4: The product filters data in a way that causes it to be reduced or "collapsed" into an unsafe value that violates an expected security property.

column2: Overly Restrictive Regular Expression
column4: A regular expression is overly restrictive
column5: which prevents dangerous values from being detected. This weakness is not about regular expression complexity. Rather
column6: it is about a regular expression that does not match all values that are intended. Consider the use of a regexp to identify acceptable values or to spot unwanted terms. An overly restrictive regexp misses some potentially security-relevant values leading to either false positives *or* false negatives
column7: depending on how the regexp is being used within the code. Consider the expression /[0-8]/ where the intention was /[0-9]/. This expression is not "complex" but the value "9" is not matched when maybe the programmer planned to check for it.

column2: Improper Handling of Values
column4: The product does not properly handle when the expected number of values for parameters
column5: fields
column6: or arguments is not provided in input
column7: or if those values are undefined.

column2: Improper Handling of Parameters
column4: The product does not properly handle when the expected number of parameters
column5: fields
column6: or arguments is not provided in input
column7: or if those parameters are undefined.

column2: Improper Handling of Structural Elements
column4: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles inputs that are related to complex structures.

column2: Improper Handling of Unexpected Data Type
column4: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular element is not the expected type
column5: e.g. it expects a digit (0-9) but is provided with a letter (A-Z).

column2: Improper Handling of Highly Compressed Data (Data Amplification)
column4: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles a compressed input with a very high compression ratio that produces a large output. An example of data amplification is a "decompression bomb
column5:
a small ZIP file that can produce a large amount of data when it is decompressed.,[CVE-2009-1955, CVE-2003-1564]
471,Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data (MAID),Not Language-Specific,The product does not properly protect an assumed-immutable element from being modified by an attacker. This occurs when a particular input is critical enough to the functioning of the application that it should not be modifiable at all, but it is. Certain resources are often assumed to be immutable when they are not, such as hidden form fields in web applications, cookies, and reverse DNS lookups.,[CVE-2002-1757, CVE-2005-1905]
472,External Control of Assumed-Immutable Web Parameter,Not Language-Specific,The web application does not sufficiently verify inputs that are assumed to be immutable but are actually externally controllable, such as hidden form fields. If a web product does not properly protect assumed-immutable values from modification in hidden form fields, parameters, cookies, or URLs, this can lead to modification of critical data. Web applications often mistakenly make the assumption that data passed to the client in hidden fields or cookies is not susceptible to tampering. Improper validation of data that are user-controllable can lead to the application processing incorrect, and often malicious, input. For example, custom cookies commonly store session data or persistent data across sessions. This kind of session data is normally involved in security related decisions on the server side, such as user authentication and access control. Thus, the cookies might contain sensitive data such as user credentials and privileges. This is a dangerous practice, as it can often lead to improper reliance on the value of the client-provided cookie by the server side application.,[CVE-2002-0108, CVE-2000-0253, CVE-2000-0254, CVE-2000-0926, CVE-2000-0101, CVE-2000-0102, CVE-2000-0758, CVE-2002-1880, CVE-2000-1234, CVE-2005-1652, CVE-2005-1784, CVE-2005-2314, CVE-2005-1682]
601,URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect'),Not Language-Specific,A web application accepts a user-controlled input that specifies a link to an external site, and uses that link in a Redirect. This simplifies phishing attacks. An http parameter may contain a URL value and could cause the web application to redirect the request to the specified URL. By modifying the URL value to a malicious site, an attacker may successfully launch a phishing scam and steal user credentials. Because the server name in the modified link is identical to the original site, phishing attempts have a more trustworthy appearance.,[CVE-2005-4206, CVE-2008-2951, CVE-2008-2052, CVE-2020-11053]
1024,Comparison of Incompatible Types,Not Language-Specific,The product performs a comparison between two entities, but the entities are of different, incompatible types that cannot be guaranteed to provide correct results when they are directly compared. In languages that are strictly typed but support casting/conversion, such as C or C++, the programmer might assume that casting one entity to the same type as another entity will ensure that the comparison will be performed correctly, but this cannot be guaranteed. In languages that are not strictly typed, such as PHP or JavaScript, there may be implicit casting/conversion to a type that the programmer is unaware of, causing unexpected results; for example, the string 123" might be converted to a number type. See examples.

column2: Improper Neutralization of Equivalent Special Elements
column4: The product correctly neutralizes certain special elements
column5: but it improperly neutralizes equivalent special elements. The product may have a fixed list of special characters it believes is complete. However
column6: there may be alternate encodings
column7: or representations that also have the same meaning. For example
column8: the product may filter out a leading slash (/) to prevent absolute path names
column9: but does not account for a tilde (~) followed by a user name
column10: which on some *nix systems could be expanded to an absolute pathname. Alternately
column11: the product might filter a dangerous "-e" command-line switch when calling an external program
column12: but it might not account for "--exec" or other switches that have the same semantics.

column2: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')
column4: The product constructs all or part of an OS command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component
column5: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended OS command when it is sent to a downstream component. This could allow attackers to execute unexpected
column6: dangerous commands directly on the operating system. This weakness can lead to a vulnerability in environments in which the attacker does not have direct access to the operating system
column7: such as in web applications. Alternately
column8: if the weakness occurs in a privileged program
column9: it could allow the attacker to specify commands that normally would not be accessible
column10: or to call alternate commands with privileges that the attacker does not have. The problem is exacerbated if the compromised process does not follow the principle of least privilege
column11: because the attacker-controlled commands may run with special system privileges that increases the amount of damage. There are at least two subtypes of OS command injection: The application intends to execute a single
column12: fixed program that is under its own control. It intends to use externally-supplied inputs as arguments to that program. For example
column13: the program might use system("nslookup [HOSTNAME]") to run nslookup and allow the user to supply a HOSTNAME
column14: which is used as an argument. Attackers cannot prevent nslookup from executing. However
column15: if the program does not remove command separators from the HOSTNAME argument
column16: attackers could place the separators into the arguments
column17: which allows them to execute their own program after nslookup has finished executing. The application accepts an input that it uses to fully select which program to run
column18: as well as which commands to use. The application simply redirects this entire command to the operating system. For example
column19: the program might use "exec([COMMAND])" to execute the [COMMAND] that was supplied by the user. If the COMMAND is under attacker control
column20: then the attacker can execute arbitrary commands or programs. If the command is being executed using functions like exec() and CreateProcess()
column21: the attacker might not be able to combine multiple commands together in the same line. From a weakness standpoint
column22: these variants represent distinct programmer errors. In the first variant
column23: the programmer clearly intends that input from untrusted parties will be part of the arguments in the command to be executed. In the second variant
column24: the programmer does not intend for the command to be accessible to any untrusted party
column25: but the programmer probably has not accounted for alternate ways in which malicious attackers can provide input.

column2: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
column4: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users. Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities occur when: Untrusted data enters a web application
column5: typically from a web request. The web application dynamically generates a web page that contains this untrusted data. During page generation
column6: the application does not prevent the data from containing content that is executable by a web browser
column7: such as JavaScript
column13: etc. A victim visits the generated web page through a web browser
column14: which contains malicious script that was injected using the untrusted data. Since the script comes from a web page that was sent by the web server
column15: the victim's web browser executes the malicious script in the context of the web server's domain. This effectively violates the intention of the web browser's same-origin policy
column16: which states that scripts in one domain should not be able to access resources or run code in a different domain. There are three main kinds of XSS: Type 1: Reflected XSS (or Non-Persistent) - The server reads data directly from the HTTP request and reflects it back in the HTTP response. Reflected XSS exploits occur when an attacker causes a victim to supply dangerous content to a vulnerable web application
column17: which is then reflected back to the victim and executed by the web browser. The most common mechanism for delivering malicious content is to include it as a parameter in a URL that is posted publicly or e-mailed directly to the victim. URLs constructed in this manner constitute the core of many phishing schemes
column18: whereby an attacker convinces a victim to visit a URL that refers to a vulnerable site. After the site reflects the attacker's content back to the victim
column19: the content is executed by the victim's browser. Type 2: Stored XSS (or Persistent) - The application stores dangerous data in a database
column22: or other trusted data store. At a later time
column23: the dangerous data is subsequently read back into the application and included in dynamic content. From an attacker's perspective
column24: the optimal place to inject malicious content is in an area that is displayed to either many users or particularly interesting users. Interesting users typically have elevated privileges in the application or interact with sensitive data that is valuable to the attacker. If one of these users executes malicious content
column25: the attacker may be able to perform privileged operations on behalf of the user or gain access to sensitive data belonging to the user. For example
column26: the attacker might inject XSS into a log message
column27: which might not be handled properly when an administrator views the logs. Type 0: DOM-Based XSS - In DOM-based XSS
column28: the client performs the injection of XSS into the page; in the other types
column29: the server performs the injection. DOM-based XSS generally involves server-controlled
column30: trusted script that is sent to the client
column31: such as Javascript that performs sanity checks on a form before the user submits it. If the server-supplied script processes user-supplied data and then injects it back into the web page (such as with dynamic HTML)
column32: then DOM-based XSS is possible. Once the malicious script is injected
column33: the attacker can perform a variety of malicious activities. The attacker could transfer private information
column34: such as cookies that may include session information
column35: from the victim's machine to the attacker. The attacker could send malicious requests to a web site on behalf of the victim
column36: which could be especially dangerous to the site if the victim has administrator privileges to manage that site. Phishing attacks could be used to emulate trusted web sites and trick the victim into entering a password
column37: allowing the attacker to compromise the victim's account on that web site. Finally
column38: the script could exploit a vulnerability in the web browser itself possibly taking over the victim's machine
column39: sometimes referred to as "drive-by hacking." In many cases
column40: the attack can be launched without the victim even being aware of it. Even with careful users
column41: attackers frequently use a variety of methods to encode the malicious portion of the attack
column42: such as URL encoding or Unicode
column43: so the request looks less suspicious.

column2: Improper Neutralization of Argument Delimiters in a Command ('Argument Injection')
column4: The product constructs a string for a command to executed by a separate component in another control sphere
column5: but it does not properly delimit the intended arguments
column6: options
column7: or switches within that command string. When creating commands using interpolation into a string
column8: developers may assume that only the arguments/options that they specify will be processed. This assumption may be even stronger when the programmer has encoded the command in a way that prevents separate commands from being provided maliciously
column9: e.g. in the case of shell metacharacters. When constructing the command
column10: the developer may use whitespace or other delimiters that are required to separate arguments when the command. However
column11: if an attacker can provide an untrusted input that contains argument-separating delimiters
column12: then the resulting command will have more arguments than intended by the developer. The attacker may then be able to change the behavior of the command. Depending on the functionality supported by the extraneous arguments

column2: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection')
column4: The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component
column5: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component. Without sufficient removal or quoting of SQL syntax in user-controllable inputs
column6: the generated SQL query can cause those inputs to be interpreted as SQL instead of ordinary user data. This can be used to alter query logic to bypass security checks
column7: or to insert additional statements that modify the back-end database
column8: possibly including execution of system commands. SQL injection has become a common issue with database-driven web sites. The flaw is easily detected
column11: any site or product package with even a minimal user base is likely to be subject to an attempted attack of this kind. This flaw depends on the fact that SQL makes no real distinction between the control and data planes.

column2: Improper Neutralization of CRLF Sequences ('CRLF Injection')
column4: The product uses CRLF (carriage return line feeds) as a special element

column6: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes CRLF sequences from inputs.

column2: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs

column2: Improper Neutralization of Delimiters
column4: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes delimiters.

column2: Duplicate Key in Associative List (Alist)

column6: duplicate key entries in an association list are not recommended and should not be allowed.

column2: Incomplete Filtering of Special Elements
column4: The product receives data from an upstream component

column2: Only Filtering Special Elements at a Specified Location
column4: The product receives data from an upstream component
column5: but only accounts for special elements at a specified location
column6: thereby missing remaining special elements that may exist before sending it to a downstream component. A filter might only account for instances of special elements when they occur: relative to a marker (e.g. "at the beginning/end of string; the second argument")
column7: or at an absolute position (e.g. "byte number 10"). This may leave special elements in the data that did not match the filter position

column2: Inappropriate Encoding for Output Context
column4: The product uses or specifies an encoding when generating output to a downstream component
column5: but the specified encoding is not the same as the encoding that is expected by the downstream component. This weakness can cause the downstream component to use a decoding method that produces different data than what the product intended to send. When the wrong encoding is used - even if closely related - the downstream component could decode the data incorrectly. This can have security consequences when the provided boundaries between control and data are inadvertently broken
column6: because the resulting data could introduce control characters or special elements that were not sent by the product. The resulting data could then be used to bypass protection mechanisms such as input validation
column7: and enable injection attacks. While using output encoding is essential for ensuring that communications between components are accurate
column8: the use of the wrong encoding - even if closely related - could cause the downstream component to misinterpret the output. For example
column9: HTML entity encoding is used for elements in the HTML body of a web page. However
column10: a programmer might use entity encoding when generating output for that is used within an attribute of an HTML tag
column11: which could contain functional Javascript that is not affected by the HTML encoding. While web applications have received the most attention for this problem
column12: this weakness could potentially apply to any type of product that uses a communications stream that could support multiple encodings.

column2: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an Expression Language Statement ('Expression Language Injection')

When the developer is not aware of the executable nature of these expressions and/or does not disable them
column6: then if an attacker can inject expressions
column7: this could lead to code execution or other unexpected behaviors.

column2: Improper Neutralization of Formula Elements in a CSV File
column4: The product saves user-provided information into a Comma-Separated Value (CSV) file
column5: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as a command when the file is opened by a spreadsheet product. User-provided data is often saved to traditional databases. This data can be exported to a CSV file
column6: which allows users to read the data using spreadsheet software such as Excel
column7: Numbers
column8: or Calc. This software interprets entries beginning with '=' as formulas
column9: which are then executed by the spreadsheet software. The software's formula language often allows methods to access hyperlinks or the local command line
column10: and frequently allows enough characters to invoke an entire script. Attackers can populate data fields which
column11: when saved to a CSV file
column12: may attempt information exfiltration or other malicious activity when automatically executed by the spreadsheet software.

column2: Missing Documentation for Design
column4: The product does not have documentation that represents how it is designed. This issue can make it more difficult to understand and maintain the product. It can make it more difficult and time-consuming to detect and/or fix vulnerabilities.

column2: Incomplete I/O Documentation
column4: The product's documentation does not adequately define inputs
column5: outputs
column6: or system/software interfaces.

column2: Incomplete Documentation of Program Execution
column4: The document does not fully define all mechanisms that are used to control or influence how product-specific programs are executed. This includes environmental variables
column5: configuration files
column6: registry keys
column7: command-line switches or options

column2: Insufficient Documentation of Error Handling Techniques
column4: The documentation does not sufficiently describe the techniques that are used for error handling
column5: exception processing
column6: or similar mechanisms. Documentation may need to cover error handling techniques at multiple layers
column7: such as module

column2: Relative Path Traversal
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize sequences such as ".." that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.

column2: Absolute Path Traversal
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize absolute path sequences such as "/abs/path" that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.

column2: Improper Resolution of Path Equivalence
column4: The product is vulnerable to file system contents disclosure through path equivalence. Path equivalence involves the use of special characters in file and directory names. The associated manipulations are intended to generate multiple names for the same object. Path equivalence is usually employed in order to circumvent access controls expressed using an incomplete set of file name or file path representations. This is different from path traversal
column5: wherein the manipulations are performed to generate a name for a different object.

column2: Improper Link Resolution Before File Access ('Link Following')
column4: The product attempts to access a file based on the filename
column5: but it does not properly prevent that filename from identifying a link or shortcut that resolves to an unintended resource.

column2: Improper Handling of File Names that Identify Virtual Resources
column4: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles a file name that identifies a "virtual" resource that is not directly specified within the directory that is associated with the file name
column5: causing the product to perform file-based operations on a resource that is not a file. Virtual file names are represented like normal file names
column6: but they are effectively aliases for other resources that do not behave like normal files. Depending on their functionality
column7: they could be alternate entities. They are not necessarily listed in directories.

column2: Creation of Temporary File With Insecure Permissions
column4: Opening temporary files without appropriate measures or controls can leave the file
column5: its contents and any function that it impacts vulnerable to attack.

column2: Creation of Temporary File in Directory with Insecure Permissions
column4: The product creates a temporary file in a directory whose permissions allow unintended actors to determine the file's existence or otherwise access that file. On some operating systems
column5: the fact that the temporary file exists may be apparent to any user with sufficient privileges to access that directory. Since the file is visible
column6: the application that is using the temporary file could be known. If one has access to list the processes on the system
column7: the attacker has gained information about what the user is doing at that time. By correlating this with the applications the user is running
column8: an attacker could potentially discover what a user's actions are. From this
column9: higher levels of security could be breached.

column2: Untrusted Search Path
column4: The product searches for critical resources using an externally-supplied search path that can point to resources that are not under the product's direct control. This might allow attackers to execute their own programs
column5: access unauthorized data files
column6: or modify configuration in unexpected ways. If the product uses a search path to locate critical resources such as programs
column7: then an attacker could modify that search path to point to a malicious program
column8: which the targeted product would then execute. The problem extends to any type of critical resource that the product trusts. Some of the most common variants of untrusted search path are: In various UNIX and Linux-based systems
column9: the PATH environment variable may be consulted to locate executable programs
column10: and LD_PRELOAD may be used to locate a separate library. In various Microsoft-based systems
column11: the PATH environment variable is consulted to locate a DLL
column12: if the DLL is not found in other paths that appear earlier in the search order.

column4: The product uses a fixed or controlled search path to find resources
column5: but one or more locations in that path can be under the control of unintended actors. Although this weakness can occur with any type of resource

column7: but the path contains a directory that can be modified by an attacker
column8: such as "/tmp" or the current working directory. In Windows-based systems
column9: when the LoadLibrary or LoadLibraryEx function is called with a DLL name that does not contain a fully qualified path
column10: the function follows a search order that includes two path elements that might be uncontrolled: the directory from which the program has been loaded the current working directory In some cases
column11: the attack can be conducted remotely
column12: such as when SMB or WebDAV network shares are used. One or more locations in that path could include the Windows drive root or its subdirectories. This often exists in Linux-based code assuming the controlled nature of the root directory (/) or its subdirectories (/etc
column14: or a code that recursively accesses the parent directory. In Windows
column15: the drive root and some of its subdirectories have weak permissions by default
column16: which makes them uncontrolled. In some Unix-based systems
column17: a PATH might be created that contains an empty element
column18: e.g. by splicing an empty variable into the PATH. This empty element can be interpreted as equivalent to the current working directory
column19: which might be an untrusted search element. In software package management frameworks (e.g.
column23: the framework may identify dependencies on third-party libraries or other packages
column24: then consult a repository that contains the desired package. The framework may search a public repository before a private repository. This could be exploited by attackers by placing a malicious package in the public repository that has the same name as a package from the private repository. The search path might not be directly under control of the developer relying on the framework
column25: but this search order effectively contains an untrusted element.

column2: Unquoted Search Path or Element
column4: The product uses a search path that contains an unquoted element
column5: in which the element contains whitespace or other separators. This can cause the product to access resources in a parent path. If a malicious individual has access to the file system
column6: it is possible to elevate privileges by inserting such a file as "C:\Program.exe" to be run by a privileged program making use of WinExec.

column2: Invocation of a Control Element at an Unnecessarily Deep Horizontal Layer
column4: The code at one architectural layer invokes code that resides at a deeper layer than the adjacent layer
column5: i.e.
column6: the invocation skips at least one layer
column7: and the invoked code is not part of a vertical utility layer that can be referenced from any horizontal layer. This issue makes it more difficult to understand and maintain the product
column8: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Data Access Operations Outside of Expected Data Manager Component
column4: The product uses a dedicated
column5: central data manager component as required by design
column6: but it contains code that performs data-access operations that do not use this data manager. This issue can make the product perform more slowly than intended
column7: since the intended central data manager may have been explicitly optimized for performance or other quality characteristics. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column8: then this performance problem might introduce a vulnerability.

column2: Parent Class with References to Child Class
column4: The code has a parent class that contains references to a child class
column5: its methods
column6: or its members. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column7: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.

column2: Data Access from Outside Expected Data Manager Component
column4: The product is intended to manage data access through a particular data manager component such as a relational or non-SQL database
column5: but it contains code that performs data access operations without using that component. When the product has a data access component
column6: the design may be intended to handle all data access operations through that component. If a data access operation is performed outside of that component
column7: then this may indicate a violation of the intended design. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column8: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.

column2: Method Containing Access of a Member Element from Another Class
column4: A method for a class performs an operation that directly accesses a member element from another class. This issue suggests poor encapsulation and makes it more difficult to understand and maintain the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Insufficient Isolation of System-Dependent Functions
column4: The product or code does not isolate system-dependent functionality into separate standalone modules. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain and/or port the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Insufficient Encapsulation of Machine-Dependent Functionality
column4: The product or code uses machine-dependent functionality
column5: but it does not sufficiently encapsulate or isolate this functionality from the rest of the code. This issue makes it more difficult to port or maintain the product
column6: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment
column5: users
column6: or associated data. The sensitive information may be valuable information on its own (such as a password)
column7: or it may be useful for launching other
column8: more serious attacks. The error message may be created in different ways: self-generated: the source code explicitly constructs the error message and delivers it externally-generated: the external environment
column10: handles the error and constructs its own message
column11: whose contents are not under direct control by the programmer An attacker may use the contents of error messages to help launch another
column13: an attempt to exploit a path traversal weakness (CWE-22) might yield the full pathname of the installed application. In turn

column2: Uncaught Exception
column4: An exception is thrown from a function
column5: but it is not caught. When an exception is not caught
column6: it may cause the program to crash or expose sensitive information.

column2: Unchecked Return Value
column4: The product does not check the return value from a method or function
column5: which can prevent it from detecting unexpected states and conditions. Two common programmer assumptions are "this function call can never fail" and "it doesn't matter if this function call fails". If an attacker can force the function to fail or otherwise return a value that is not expected
column6: then the subsequent program logic could lead to a vulnerability
column7: because the product is not in a state that the programmer assumes. For example
column8: if the program calls a function to drop privileges but does not check the return code to ensure that privileges were successfully dropped
column9: then the program will continue to operate with the higher privileges.

column2: Incorrect Check of Function Return Value
column4: The product incorrectly checks a return value from a function
column5: which prevents it from detecting errors or exceptional conditions. Important and common functions will return some value about the success of its actions. This will alert the program whether or not to handle any errors caused by that function.

column2: Detection of Error Condition Without Action
column4: The product detects a specific error
column5: but takes no actions to handle the error.

column2: Unchecked Error Condition
column4: [PLANNED FOR DEPRECATION. SEE MAINTENANCE NOTES AND CONSIDER CWE-252
column5: CWE-248
column6: OR CWE-1069.] Ignoring exceptions and other error conditions may allow an attacker to induce unexpected behavior unnoticed.

column2: Missing Report of Error Condition
column4: The product encounters an error but does not provide a status code or return value to indicate that an error has occurred.

column2: Return of Wrong Status Code
column4: A function or operation returns an incorrect return value or status code that does not indicate an error
column5: but causes the product to modify its behavior based on the incorrect result. This can lead to unpredictable behavior. If the function is used to make security-critical decisions or provide security-critical information
column6: then the wrong status code can cause the product to assume that an action is safe
column7: even when it is not.

column2: Unexpected Status Code or Return Value
column4: The product does not properly check when a function or operation returns a value that is legitimate for the function
column5: but is not expected by the product.

column2: Use of NullPointerException Catch to Detect NULL Pointer Dereference
column4: Catching NullPointerException should not be used as an alternative to programmatic checks to prevent dereferencing a null pointer. Programmers typically catch NullPointerException under three circumstances: The program contains a null pointer dereference. Catching the resulting exception was easier than fixing the underlying problem. The program explicitly throws a NullPointerException to signal an error condition. The code is part of a test harness that supplies unexpected input to the classes under test. Of these three circumstances
column5: only the last is acceptable.

column2: Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception
column4: Catching overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities. Multiple catch blocks can get ugly and repetitive
column5: but "condensing" catch blocks by catching a high-level class like Exception can obscure exceptions that deserve special treatment or that should not be caught at this point in the program. Catching an overly broad exception essentially defeats the purpose of Java's typed exceptions
column6: and can become particularly dangerous if the program grows and begins to throw new types of exceptions. The new exception types will not receive any attention.

column2: Declaration of Throws for Generic Exception
column4: Throwing overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities. Declaring a method to throw Exception or Throwable makes it difficult for callers to perform proper error handling and error recovery. Java's exception mechanism
column5: for example
column6: is set up to make it easy for callers to anticipate what can go wrong and write code to handle each specific exceptional circumstance. Declaring that a method throws a generic form of exception defeats this system.

column2: Missing Standardized Error Handling Mechanism
column4: The product does not use a standardized method for handling errors throughout the code
column5: which might introduce inconsistent error handling and resultant weaknesses. If the product handles error messages individually
column6: on a one-by-one basis
column7: this is likely to result in inconsistent error handling. The causes of errors may be lost. Also
column8: detailed information about the causes of an error may be unintentionally returned to the user.

column2: Return Inside Finally Block
column4: The code has a return statement inside a finally block
column5: which will cause any thrown exception in the try block to be discarded.

column2: Uncaught Exception in Servlet
column4: The Servlet does not catch all exceptions
column5: which may reveal sensitive debugging information. When a Servlet throws an exception
column6: the default error response the Servlet container sends back to the user typically includes debugging information. This information is of great value to an attacker. For example
column7: a stack trace might show the attacker a malformed SQL query string
column8: the type of database being used
column9: and the version of the application container. This information enables the attacker to target known vulnerabilities in these components.

column2: Reachable Assertion
column4: The product contains an assert() or similar statement that can be triggered by an attacker
column5: which leads to an application exit or other behavior that is more severe than necessary. While assertion is good for catching logic errors and reducing the chances of reaching more serious vulnerability conditions
column6: it can still lead to a denial of service. For example
column7: if a server handles multiple simultaneous connections
column8: and an assert() occurs in one single connection that causes all other connections to be dropped
column9: this is a reachable assertion that leads to a denial of service.

column2: Missing Custom Error Page
column4: The product does not return custom error pages to the user
column5: possibly exposing sensitive information.

column2: Empty Exception Block
column4: An invokable code block contains an exception handling block that does not contain any code
column5: i.e. is empty. When an exception handling block (such as a Catch and Finally block) is used
column6: but that block is empty
column7: this can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column8: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.

column2: Use of Incorrect Operator
column4: The product accidentally uses the wrong operator
column5: which changes the logic in security-relevant ways. These types of errors are generally the result of a typo by the programmer.

column2: Expression is Always False
column4: The product contains an expression that will always evaluate to false.

column2: Expression is Always True
column4: The product contains an expression that will always evaluate to true.

column2: Attempt to Access Child of a Non-structure Pointer
column4: Casting a non-structure type to a structure type and accessing a field can lead to memory access errors or data corruption.

column2: Comparison of Object References Instead of Object Contents
column4: The product compares object references instead of the contents of the objects themselves
column5: preventing it from detecting equivalent objects. For example
column6: in Java
column7: comparing objects using == usually produces deceptive results
column8: since the == operator compares object references rather than values; often
column9: this means that using == for strings is actually comparing the strings' references

column2: Operator Precedence Logic Error
column4: The product uses an expression in which operator precedence causes incorrect logic to be used. While often just a bug
column5: operator precedence logic errors can have serious consequences if they are used in security-critical code
column6: such as making an authentication decision.

column2: Deployment of Wrong Handler
column4: The wrong "handler" is assigned to process an object. An example of deploying the wrong handler would be calling a servlet to reveal source code of a .JSP file
column5: or automatically "determining" type of the object even if it is contradictory to an explicitly specified type.

column2: Missing Handler
column4: A handler is not available or implemented. When an exception is thrown and not caught
column5: the process has given up an opportunity to decide if a given failure or event is worth a change in execution.

column2: Dangerous Signal Handler not Disabled During Sensitive Operations
column4: The product uses a signal handler that shares state with other signal handlers
column5: but it does not properly mask or prevent those signal handlers from being invoked while the original signal handler is still running. During the execution of a signal handler
column6: it can be interrupted by another handler when a different signal is sent. If the two handlers share state - such as global variables - then an attacker can corrupt the state by sending another signal before the first handler has completed execution.

column2: Unparsed Raw Web Content Delivery
column4: The product stores raw content or supporting code under the web document root with an extension that is not specifically handled by the server. If code is stored in a file with an extension such as ".inc" or ".pl"
column5: and the web server does not have a handler for that extension
column6: then the server will likely send the contents of the file directly to the requester without the pre-processing that was expected. When that file contains sensitive information such as database credentials
column7: this may allow the attacker to compromise the application or associated components.

column2: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type
column4: The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

column2: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Sent Data
column4: The code transmits data to another actor
column5: but a portion of the data includes sensitive information that should not be accessible to that actor. Sensitive information could include data that is sensitive in and of itself (such as credentials or private messages)
column6: or otherwise useful in the further exploitation of the system (such as internal file system structure).

column2: Observable Response Discrepancy
column4: The product provides different responses to incoming requests in a way that reveals internal state information to an unauthorized actor outside of the intended control sphere. This issue frequently occurs during authentication
column5: where a difference in failed-login messages could allow an attacker to determine if the username is valid or not. These exposures can be inadvertent (bug) or intentional (design).

column2: Observable Behavioral Discrepancy
column4: The product's behaviors indicate important differences that may be observed by unauthorized actors in a way that reveals (1) its internal state or decision process
column5: or (2) differences from other products with equivalent functionality. Ideally
column6: a product should provide as little information about its internal operations as possible. Otherwise
column7: attackers could use knowledge of these internal operations to simplify or optimize their attack. In some cases
column8: behavioral discrepancies can be used by attackers to form a side channel.

column2: Observable Timing Discrepancy
column4: Two separate operations in a product require different amounts of time to complete
column5: in a way that is observable to an actor and reveals security-relevant information about the state of the product
column6: such as whether a particular operation was successful or not. In security-relevant contexts
column7: even small variations in timing can be exploited by attackers to indirectly infer certain details about the product's internal operations. For example
column9: attackers can use timing differences to infer certain properties about a private key
column10: making the key easier to guess. Timing discrepancies effectively form a timing side channel.

column4: The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment
column5: users
column6: or associated data. The sensitive information may be valuable information on its own (such as a password)
column7: or it may be useful for launching other
column8: more serious attacks. The error message may be created in different ways: self-generated: the source code explicitly constructs the error message and delivers it externally-generated: the external environment

column11: whose contents are not under direct control by the programmer An attacker may use the contents of error messages to help launch another
column13: an attempt to exploit a path traversal weakness (CWE-22) might yield the full pathname of the installed application. In turn
column14: this could be used to select the proper number of ".." sequences to navigate to the targeted file. An attack using SQL injection (CWE-89) might not initially succeed
column15: but an error message could reveal the malformed query
column16: which would expose query logic and possibly even passwords or other sensitive information used within the query.

column2: Improper Removal of Sensitive Information Before Storage or Transfer
column4: The product stores
column5: transfers
column6: or shares a resource that contains sensitive information
column7: but it does not properly remove that information before the product makes the resource available to unauthorized actors. Resources that may contain sensitive data include documents
column11: etc. While this data may be useful to an individual user or small set of users who share the resource
column12: it may need to be removed before the resource can be shared outside of the trusted group. The process of removal is sometimes called cleansing or scrubbing. For example
column13: a product for editing documents might not remove sensitive data such as reviewer comments or the local pathname where the document is stored. Or
column14: a proxy might not remove an internal IP address from headers before making an outgoing request to an Internet site.

column2: Exposure of Sensitive Information Due to Incompatible Policies
column4: The product's intended functionality exposes information to certain actors in accordance with the developer's security policy
column5: but this information is regarded as sensitive according to the intended security policies of other stakeholders such as the product's administrator
column6: users
column7: or others whose information is being processed. When handling information
column8: the developer must consider whether the information is regarded as sensitive by different stakeholders
column9: such as users or administrators. Each stakeholder effectively has its own intended security policy that the product is expected to uphold. When a developer does not treat that information as sensitive
column10: this can introduce a vulnerability that violates the expectations of the product's users.

column2: Invocation of Process Using Visible Sensitive Information
column4: A process is invoked with sensitive command-line arguments
column5: environment variables
column6: or other elements that can be seen by other processes on the operating system. Many operating systems allow a user to list information about processes that are owned by other users. Other users could see information such as command line arguments or environment variable settings. When this data contains sensitive information such as credentials
column7: it might allow other users to launch an attack against the product or related resources.

column2: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Debugging Code
column4: The product inserts sensitive information into debugging code
column5: which could expose this information if the debugging code is not disabled in production. When debugging
column6: it may be necessary to report detailed information to the programmer. However
column7: if the debugging code is not disabled when the product is operating in a production environment
column8: then this sensitive information may be exposed to attackers.

column2: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information
column4: The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere. Because the information is stored in cleartext (i.e.
column5: unencrypted)
column6: attackers could potentially read it. Even if the information is encoded in a way that is not human-readable
column7: certain techniques could determine which encoding is being used
column8: then decode the information. When organizations adopt cloud services
column9: it can be easier for attackers to access the data from anywhere on the Internet. In some systems/environments such as cloud
column10: the use of "double encryption" (at both the software and hardware layer) might be required
column11: and the developer might be solely responsible for both layers
column12: instead of shared responsibility with the administrator of the broader system/environment.

column2: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information
column4: The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors. Many communication channels can be "sniffed" (monitored) by adversaries during data transmission. For example
column5: in networking
column6: packets can traverse many intermediary nodes from the source to the destination
column7: whether across the internet
column10: etc. Some actors might have privileged access to a network interface or any link along the channel
column12: but they might not be authorized to collect the underlying data. As a result
column13: network traffic could be sniffed by adversaries
column14: spilling security-critical data. Applicable communication channels are not limited to software products. Applicable channels include hardware-specific technologies such as internal hardware networks and external debug channels
column15: supporting remote JTAG debugging. When mitigations are not applied to combat adversaries within the product's threat model
column16: this weakness significantly lowers the difficulty of exploitation by such adversaries. When full communications are recorded or logged
column17: such as with a packet dump
column18: an adversary could attempt to obtain the dump long after the transmission has occurred and try to "sniff" the cleartext from the recorded communications in the dump itself.

column2: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor
column4: The product does not properly prevent a person's private
column5: personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected. There are many types of sensitive information that products must protect from attackers
column6: including system data
column7: communications
column11: and an individual's personal (private) information. Private personal information may include a password
column16: etc. Private information is important to consider whether the person is a user of the product
column17: or part of a data set that is processed by the product. An exposure of private information does not necessarily prevent the product from working properly
column18: and in fact the exposure might be intended by the developer
column19: e.g. as part of data sharing with other organizations. However
column20: the exposure of personal private information can still be undesirable or explicitly prohibited by law or regulation. Some types of private information include: Government identifiers
column21: such as Social Security Numbers Contact information
column22: such as home addresses and telephone numbers Geographic location - where the user is (or was) Employment history Financial data - such as credit card numbers
column27: or audio Behavioral patterns - such as web surfing history
column29: etc. Relationships (and types of relationships) with others - family
column38: prescription records Account passwords and other credentials Some of this information may be characterized as PII (Personally Identifiable Information)
column40: etc. Categories of private information may overlap or vary based on the intended usage or the policies and practices of a particular industry. Sometimes data that is not labeled as private can have a privacy implication in a different context. For example
column41: student identification numbers are usually not considered private because there is no explicit and publicly-available mapping to an individual student's personal information. However
column42: if a school generates identification numbers based on student social security numbers
column43: then the identification numbers should be considered private.

column2: Exposure of Sensitive System Information to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
column4: The product does not properly prevent sensitive system-level information from being accessed by unauthorized actors who do not have the same level of access to the underlying system as the product does. Network-based products
column5: such as web applications
column6: often run on top of an operating system or similar environment. When the product communicates with outside parties
column7: details about the underlying system are expected to remain hidden
column8: such as path names for data files
column12: etc. This system information may be provided by the product itself
column13: or buried within diagnostic or debugging messages. Debugging information helps an adversary learn about the system and form an attack plan. An information exposure occurs when system data or debugging information leaves the program through an output stream or logging function that makes it accessible to unauthorized parties. Using other weaknesses
column14: an attacker could cause errors to occur; the response to these errors can reveal detailed system information
column15: along with other impacts. An attacker can use messages that reveal technologies
column17: and product versions to tune the attack against known vulnerabilities in these technologies. A product may use diagnostic methods that provide significant implementation details such as stack traces as part of its error handling mechanism.

column2: Use of Cache Containing Sensitive Information
column4: The code uses a cache that contains sensitive information
column5: but the cache can be read by an actor outside of the intended control sphere. Applications may use caches to improve efficiency when communicating with remote entities or performing intensive calculations. A cache maintains a pool of objects
column6: threads
column7: connections
column11: or other resources to minimize the time it takes to initialize and access these resources. If the cache is accessible to unauthorized actors
column12: attackers can read the cache and obtain this sensitive information.

column2: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File
column4: Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information. While logging all information may be helpful during development stages
column5: it is important that logging levels be set appropriately before a product ships so that sensitive user data and system information are not accidentally exposed to potential attackers. Different log files may be produced and stored for: Server log files (e.g. server.log). This can give information on whatever application left the file. Usually this can give full path names and system information
column6: and sometimes usernames and passwords. log files that are used for debugging

column2: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code
column4: Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example
column5: obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

column2: Storage of Sensitive Data in a Mechanism without Access Control
column4: The product stores sensitive information in a file system or device that does not have built-in access control. While many modern file systems or devices utilize some form of access control in order to restrict access to data
column5: not all storage mechanisms have this capability. For example
column6: memory cards
column7: floppy disks
column9: and USB devices are typically made accessible to any user within the system. This can become a problem when sensitive data is stored in these mechanisms in a multi-user environment
column10: because anybody on the system can read or write this data. On Android devices
column11: external storage is typically globally readable and writable by other applications on the device. External storage may also be easily accessible through the mobile device's USB connection or physically accessible through the device's memory card port.

column2: Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Metadata
column4: The product prevents direct access to a resource containing sensitive information
column5: but it does not sufficiently limit access to metadata that is derived from the original
column6: sensitive information. Developers might correctly prevent unauthorized access to a database or other resource containing sensitive information
column7: but they might not consider that portions of the original information might also be recorded in metadata
column10: or other resources. If these resources are not also restricted
column11: then attackers might be able to extract some or all of the original information
column12: or otherwise infer some details. For example
column13: an attacker could specify search terms that are known to be unique to a particular person
column14: or view metadata such as activity or creation dates in order to identify usage patterns.

column2: Sensitive Information in Resource Not Removed Before Reuse
column4: The product releases a resource such as memory or a file so that it can be made available for reuse
column5: but it does not clear or "zeroize" the information contained in the resource before the product performs a critical state transition or makes the resource available for reuse by other entities. When resources are released
column6: they can be made available for reuse. For example
column7: after memory is de-allocated
column8: an operating system may make the memory available to another process
column9: or disk space may be reallocated when a file is deleted. As removing information requires time and additional resources
column10: operating systems do not usually clear the previously written information. Even when the resource is reused by the same process
column11: this weakness can arise when new data is not as large as the old data
column12: which leaves portions of the old data still available. Equivalent errors can occur in other situations where the length of data is variable but the associated data structure is not. If memory is not cleared after use
column13: the information may be read by less trustworthy parties when the memory is reallocated. This weakness can apply in hardware
column14: such as when a device or system switches between power
column16: or debug states during normal operation
column17: or when execution changes to different users or privilege levels.

column2: External Initialization of Trusted Variables or Data Stores
column4: The product initializes critical internal variables or data stores using inputs that can be modified by untrusted actors. A product system should be reluctant to trust variables that have been initialized outside of its trust boundary

column2: Improper Use of Validation Framework
column4: The product does not use
column5: or incorrectly uses

column8: an attacker may use this very security feature to deny service to legitimate system users. It is therefore important to ensure that the account lockout security mechanism is not overly restrictive.

column5: data is untrusted. On the other side of the line

column7: using a uniquely generated seed from a cryptographically secure source PRNGs require a seed as input to generate a stream of numbers that are functionally indistinguishable from random numbers. While the output is
