but this can lead to overuse of CWE-200 in CWE mapping. From the CWE perspective, loss of confidentiality is a technical impact that can arise from dozens of different weaknesses, such as insecure file permissions or out-of-bounds read. CWE-200 and its lower-level descendants are intended to cover the mistakes that occur in behaviors that explicitly manage, store, transfer, or cleanse sensitive information.,[CVE-2001-1483, CVE-2001-1528, CVE-2004-2150, CVE-2005-1205, CVE-2002-1725, CVE-2002-0515, CVE-2004-0778, CVE-2000-1117, CVE-2003-0190, CVE-2008-2049, CVE-2007-5172, CVE-2008-4638, CVE-2007-1409, CVE-2005-0603, CVE-2004-2268, CVE-2003-1078, CVE-2022-0708]
1258,Exposure of Sensitive System Information Due to Uncleared Debug Information,Not Language-Specific,The hardware does not fully clear security-sensitive values, such as keys and intermediate values in cryptographic operations, when debug mode is entered. Security sensitive values, keys, intermediate steps of cryptographic operations, etc. are stored in temporary registers in the hardware. If these values are not cleared when debug mode is entered they may be accessed by a debugger allowing sensitive information to be accessible by untrusted parties.,[]
1295,Debug Messages Revealing Unnecessary Information,Not Language-Specific,The product fails to adequately prevent the revealing of unnecessary and potentially sensitive system information within debugging messages. Debug messages are messages that help troubleshoot an issue by revealing the internal state of the system. For example, debug data in design can be exposed through internal memory array dumps or boot logs through interfaces like UART via TAP commands, scan chain, etc. Thus, the more information contained in a debug message, the easier it is to debug. However, there is also the risk of revealing information that could help an attacker either decipher a vulnerability, and/or gain a better understanding of the system. Thus, this extra information could lower the security by obscurity" factor. While "security by obscurity" alone is insufficient
column27: it can help as a part of "Defense-in-depth".

column2: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Sent Data
column4: The code transmits data to another actor
column5: but a portion of the data includes sensitive information that should not be accessible to that actor. Sensitive information could include data that is sensitive in and of itself (such as credentials or private messages)
column6: or otherwise useful in the further exploitation of the system (such as internal file system structure).

column2: Use of GET Request Method With Sensitive Query Strings
column4: The web application uses the HTTP GET method to process a request and includes sensitive information in the query string of that request. The query string for the URL could be saved in the browser's history
column5: passed through Referers to other web sites
column6: stored in web logs
column7: or otherwise recorded in other sources. If the query string contains sensitive information such as session identifiers
column8: then attackers can use this information to launch further attacks.

column2: Observable Discrepancy
column4: The product behaves differently or sends different responses under different circumstances in a way that is observable to an unauthorized actor
column5: which exposes security-relevant information about the state of the product
column6: such as whether a particular operation was successful or not. Discrepancies can take many forms
column7: and variations may be detectable in timing
column9: communications such as replies or requests
column10: or general behavior. These discrepancies can reveal information about the product's operation or internal state to an unauthorized actor. In some cases
column11: discrepancies can be used by attackers to form a side channel.

column2: Improper Protection of Physical Side Channels
column4: The device does not contain sufficient protection mechanisms to prevent physical side channels from exposing sensitive information due to patterns in physically observable phenomena such as variations in power consumption
column5: electromagnetic emissions (EME)
column6: or acoustic emissions. An adversary could monitor and measure physical phenomena to detect patterns and make inferences
column7: even if it is not possible to extract the information in the digital domain. Physical side channels have been well-studied for decades in the context of breaking implementations of cryptographic algorithms or other attacks against security features. These side channels may be easily observed by an adversary with physical access to the device
column8: or using a tool that is in close proximity. If the adversary can monitor hardware operation and correlate its data processing with power
column11: the adversary might be able to recover of secret keys and data.

column2: Comparison Logic is Vulnerable to Power Side-Channel Attacks
column4: A device's real time power consumption may be monitored during security token evaluation and the information gleaned may be used to determine the value of the reference token. The power consumed by a device may be instrumented and monitored in real time. If the algorithm for evaluating security tokens is not sufficiently robust
column5: the power consumption may vary by token entry comparison against the reference value. Further
column6: if retries are unlimited
column7: the power difference between a "good" entry and a "bad" entry may be observed and used to determine whether each entry itself is correct thereby allowing unauthorized parties to calculate the reference value.

column2: Non-Transparent Sharing of Microarchitectural Resources
column4: Hardware structures shared across execution contexts (e.g.
column5: caches and branch predictors) can violate the expected architecture isolation between contexts. Modern processors use techniques such as out-of-order execution
column6: speculation
column7: prefetching
column9: and caching to increase performance. Details about the implementation of these techniques are hidden from the programmer's view. This is problematic when the hardware implementation of these techniques results in resources being shared across supposedly isolated contexts. Contention for shared resources between different contexts opens covert channels that allow malicious programs executing in one context to recover information from another context. Some examples of shared micro-architectural resources that have been used to leak information between contexts are caches
column11: and load or store buffers. Speculative and out-of-order execution provides an attacker with increased control over which data is leaked through the covert channel. If the extent of resource sharing between contexts in the design microarchitecture is undocumented
column12: it is extremely difficult to ensure system assets are protected against disclosure.

column2: Observable Response Discrepancy
column4: The product provides different responses to incoming requests in a way that reveals internal state information to an unauthorized actor outside of the intended control sphere. This issue frequently occurs during authentication
column5: where a difference in failed-login messages could allow an attacker to determine if the username is valid or not. These exposures can be inadvertent (bug) or intentional (design).

column2: Observable Behavioral Discrepancy
column4: The product's behaviors indicate important differences that may be observed by unauthorized actors in a way that reveals (1) its internal state or decision process
column5: or (2) differences from other products with equivalent functionality. Ideally
column6: a product should provide as little information about its internal operations as possible. Otherwise
column7: attackers could use knowledge of these internal operations to simplify or optimize their attack. In some cases
column8: behavioral discrepancies can be used by attackers to form a side channel.

column2: Observable Internal Behavioral Discrepancy
column4: The product performs multiple behaviors that are combined to produce a single result
column5: but the individual behaviors are observable separately in a way that allows attackers to reveal internal state or internal decision points. Ideally
column6: a product should provide as little information as possible to an attacker. Any hints that the attacker may be making progress can then be used to simplify or optimize the attack. For example
column7: in a login procedure that requires a username and password
column8: ultimately there is only one decision: success or failure. However
column10: two separate actions are performed: determining if the username exists
column11: and checking if the password is correct. If the product behaves differently based on whether the username exists or not
column12: then the attacker only needs to concentrate on the password.

column2: Observable Behavioral Discrepancy With Equivalent Products
column4: The product operates in an environment in which its existence or specific identity should not be known
column5: but it behaves differently than other products with equivalent functionality
column6: in a way that is observable to an attacker. For many kinds of products
column7: multiple products may be available that perform the same functionality
column10: or intrusion detection system. Attackers often perform "fingerprinting
column11:
which uses discrepancies in order to identify which specific product is in use. Once the specific product has been identified, the attacks can be made more customized and efficient. Often, an organization might intentionally allow the specific product to be identifiable. However, in some environments, the ability to identify a distinct product is unacceptable, and it is expected that every product would behave in exactly the same way. In these more restricted environments, a behavioral difference might pose an unacceptable risk if it makes it easier to identify the product's vendor, model, configuration, version, etc.,[CVE-2002-0208, CVE-2004-2252, CVE-2000-1142]
208,Observable Timing Discrepancy,Not Language-Specific,Two separate operations in a product require different amounts of time to complete, in a way that is observable to an actor and reveals security-relevant information about the state of the product, such as whether a particular operation was successful or not. In security-relevant contexts, even small variations in timing can be exploited by attackers to indirectly infer certain details about the product's internal operations. For example, in some cryptographic algorithms, attackers can use timing differences to infer certain properties about a private key, making the key easier to guess. Timing discrepancies effectively form a timing side channel.,[CVE-2003-0078, CVE-2000-1117, CVE-2003-0637, CVE-2003-0190, CVE-2004-1602, CVE-2005-0918]
1254,Incorrect Comparison Logic Granularity,Not Language-Specific,The product's comparison logic is performed over a series of steps rather than across the entire string in one operation. If there is a comparison logic failure on one of these steps, the operation may be vulnerable to a timing attack that can result in the interception of the process for nefarious purposes. Comparison logic is used to compare a variety of objects including passwords, Message Authentication Codes (MACs), and responses to verification challenges. When comparison logic is implemented at a finer granularity (e.g., byte-by-byte comparison) and breaks in the case of a comparison failure, an attacker can exploit this implementation to identify when exactly the failure occurred. With multiple attempts, the attacker may be able to guesses the correct password/response to challenge and elevate their privileges.,[CVE-2014-0984]
209,Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information,Not Language-Specific,The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data. The sensitive information may be valuable information on its own (such as a password), or it may be useful for launching other, more serious attacks. The error message may be created in different ways: self-generated: the source code explicitly constructs the error message and delivers it externally-generated: the external environment, such as a language interpreter, handles the error and constructs its own message, whose contents are not under direct control by the programmer An attacker may use the contents of error messages to help launch another, more focused attack. For example, an attempt to exploit a path traversal weakness (CWE-22) might yield the full pathname of the installed application. In turn, this could be used to select the proper number of .." sequences to navigate to the targeted file. An attack using SQL injection (CWE-89) might not initially succeed
column12: but an error message could reveal the malformed query
column13: which would expose query logic and possibly even passwords or other sensitive information used within the query.

column2: Self-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: The product identifies an error condition and creates its own diagnostic or error messages that contain sensitive information.

column2: Externally-Generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: The product performs an operation that triggers an external diagnostic or error message that is not directly generated or controlled by the product
column5: such as an error generated by the programming language interpreter that a software application uses. The error can contain sensitive system information.

column2: Exposure of Information Through Shell Error Message
column4: A command shell error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in the web application code. In many cases
column5: an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause these errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

column2: Servlet Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: A servlet error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in your web application code and may provide useful information to an attacker.

column2: Java Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: In many cases
column5: an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause unhandled exception errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

column2: Server-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: Certain conditions
column5: such as network failure
column6: will cause a server error message to be displayed. While error messages in and of themselves are not dangerous
column7: per se
column8: it is what an attacker can glean from them that might cause eventual problems.

column2: Exposure of Sensitive Information Due to Incompatible Policies
column4: The product's intended functionality exposes information to certain actors in accordance with the developer's security policy
column5: but this information is regarded as sensitive according to the intended security policies of other stakeholders such as the product's administrator
column6: users
column7: or others whose information is being processed. When handling information
column8: the developer must consider whether the information is regarded as sensitive by different stakeholders
column9: such as users or administrators. Each stakeholder effectively has its own intended security policy that the product is expected to uphold. When a developer does not treat that information as sensitive
column10: this can introduce a vulnerability that violates the expectations of the product's users.

column2: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Debugging Code
column4: The product inserts sensitive information into debugging code
column5: which could expose this information if the debugging code is not disabled in production. When debugging
column6: it may be necessary to report detailed information to the programmer. However
column7: if the debugging code is not disabled when the product is operating in a production environment
column8: then this sensitive information may be exposed to attackers.

column2: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor
column4: The product does not properly prevent a person's private
column5: personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected. There are many types of sensitive information that products must protect from attackers
column6: including system data
column7: communications
column11: and an individual's personal (private) information. Private personal information may include a password
column16: etc. Private information is important to consider whether the person is a user of the product
column17: or part of a data set that is processed by the product. An exposure of private information does not necessarily prevent the product from working properly
column18: and in fact the exposure might be intended by the developer
column19: e.g. as part of data sharing with other organizations. However
column20: the exposure of personal private information can still be undesirable or explicitly prohibited by law or regulation. Some types of private information include: Government identifiers
column21: such as Social Security Numbers Contact information
column22: such as home addresses and telephone numbers Geographic location - where the user is (or was) Employment history Financial data - such as credit card numbers
column27: or audio Behavioral patterns - such as web surfing history
column29: etc. Relationships (and types of relationships) with others - family
column38: prescription records Account passwords and other credentials Some of this information may be characterized as PII (Personally Identifiable Information)
column40: etc. Categories of private information may overlap or vary based on the intended usage or the policies and practices of a particular industry. Sometimes data that is not labeled as private can have a privacy implication in a different context. For example
column41: student identification numbers are usually not considered private because there is no explicit and publicly-available mapping to an individual student's personal information. However
column42: if a school generates identification numbers based on student social security numbers
column43: then the identification numbers should be considered private.

column2: Exposure of Sensitive System Information to an Unauthorized Control Sphere
column4: The product does not properly prevent sensitive system-level information from being accessed by unauthorized actors who do not have the same level of access to the underlying system as the product does. Network-based products
column5: such as web applications
column6: often run on top of an operating system or similar environment. When the product communicates with outside parties
column7: details about the underlying system are expected to remain hidden
column8: such as path names for data files
column12: etc. This system information may be provided by the product itself
column13: or buried within diagnostic or debugging messages. Debugging information helps an adversary learn about the system and form an attack plan. An information exposure occurs when system data or debugging information leaves the program through an output stream or logging function that makes it accessible to unauthorized parties. Using other weaknesses
column14: an attacker could cause errors to occur; the response to these errors can reveal detailed system information
column15: along with other impacts. An attacker can use messages that reveal technologies
column17: and product versions to tune the attack against known vulnerabilities in these technologies. A product may use diagnostic methods that provide significant implementation details such as stack traces as part of its error handling mechanism.

column2: Invocation of Process Using Visible Sensitive Information
column4: A process is invoked with sensitive command-line arguments
column5: environment variables
column6: or other elements that can be seen by other processes on the operating system. Many operating systems allow a user to list information about processes that are owned by other users. Other users could see information such as command line arguments or environment variable settings. When this data contains sensitive information such as credentials
column7: it might allow other users to launch an attack against the product or related resources.

column2: Exposure of Information Through Directory Listing
column4: A directory listing is inappropriately exposed
column5: yielding potentially sensitive information to attackers. A directory listing provides an attacker with the complete index of all the resources located inside of the directory. The specific risks and consequences vary depending on which files are listed and accessible.

column2: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Externally-Accessible File or Directory
column4: The product places sensitive information into files or directories that are accessible to actors who are allowed to have access to the files
column5: but not to the sensitive information.

column2: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File
column4: Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information. While logging all information may be helpful during development stages
column5: it is important that logging levels be set appropriately before a product ships so that sensitive user data and system information are not accidentally exposed to potential attackers. Different log files may be produced and stored for: Server log files (e.g. server.log). This can give information on whatever application left the file. Usually this can give full path names and system information
column6: and sometimes usernames and passwords. log files that are used for debugging

column2: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code
column4: Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example
column5: obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

column2: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Test Code
column4: Accessible test applications can pose a variety of security risks. Since developers or administrators rarely consider that someone besides themselves would even know about the existence of these applications
column5: it is common for them to contain sensitive information or functions.

column2: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in an Include File
column4: If an include file source is accessible
column5: the file can contain usernames and passwords
column6: as well as sensitive information pertaining to the application and system.

column2: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Comments
column4: While adding general comments is very useful
column5: some programmers tend to leave important data
column6: such as: filenames related to the web application
column7: old links or links which were not meant to be browsed by users
column9: etc. An attacker who finds these comments can map the application's structure and files
column10: expose hidden parts of the site
column11: and study the fragments of code to reverse engineer the application
column12: which may help develop further attacks against the site.

column2: Exposure of WSDL File Containing Sensitive Information
column4: The Web services architecture may require exposing a Web Service Definition Language (WSDL) file that contains information on the publicly accessible services and how callers of these services should interact with them (e.g. what parameters they expect and what types they return). An information exposure may occur if any of the following apply: The WSDL file is accessible to a wider audience than intended. The WSDL file contains information on the methods/services that should not be publicly accessible or information about deprecated methods. This problem is made more likely due to the WSDL often being automatically generated from the code. Information in the WSDL file helps guess names/locations of methods/resources that should not be publicly accessible.

column2: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory
column5: but the product does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory. Many file operations are intended to take place within a restricted directory. By using special elements such as ".." and "/" separators
column6: attackers can escape outside of the restricted location to access files or directories that are elsewhere on the system. One of the most common special elements is the "../" sequence
column7: which in most modern operating systems is interpreted as the parent directory of the current location. This is referred to as relative path traversal. Path traversal also covers the use of absolute pathnames such as "/usr/local/bin"
column8: which may also be useful in accessing unexpected files. This is referred to as absolute path traversal. In many programming languages
column9: the injection of a null byte (the 0 or NUL) may allow an attacker to truncate a generated filename to widen the scope of attack. For example
column10: the product may add ".txt" to any pathname
column11: thus limiting the attacker to text files
column12: but a null injection may effectively remove this restriction.

column2: Relative Path Traversal
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize sequences such as ".." that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.

column2: Path Traversal: '../filedir'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The "../" manipulation is the canonical manipulation for operating systems that use "/" as directory separators
column6: such as UNIX- and Linux-based systems. In some cases
column7: it is useful for bypassing protection schemes in environments for which "/" is supported but not the primary separator
column9: which uses "\" but can also accept "/".

column2: Path Traversal: '/../filedir'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize "/../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. Sometimes a program checks for "../" at the beginning of the input
column6: so a "/../" can bypass that check.

column2: Path Traversal: '/dir/../filename'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize "/dir/../filename" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The '/dir/../filename' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. Sometimes a program only checks for "../" at the beginning of the input
column6: so a "/../" can bypass that check.

column2: Path Traversal: 'dir/../../filename'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize multiple internal "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The 'directory/../../filename' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. Sometimes a program only removes one "../" sequence
column6: so multiple "../" can bypass that check. Alternately
column7: this manipulation could be used to bypass a check for "../" at the beginning of the pathname
column8: moving up more than one directory level.

column2: Path Traversal: '..\filedir'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize "..\" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The '..\' manipulation is the canonical manipulation for operating systems that use "\" as directory separators
column6: such as Windows. However
column7: it is also useful for bypassing path traversal protection schemes that only assume that the "/" separator is valid.

column2: Path Traversal: '\..\filename'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize '\..\filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. This is similar to CWE-25
column6: except using "\" instead of "/". Sometimes a program checks for "..\" at the beginning of the input
column7: so a "\..\" can bypass that check. It is also useful for bypassing path traversal protection schemes that only assume that the "/" separator is valid.

column2: Path Traversal: '\dir\..\filename'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize '\dir\..\filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. This is similar to CWE-26
column6: except using "\" instead of "/". The '\dir\..\filename' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. Sometimes a program only checks for "..\" at the beginning of the input
column7: so a "\..\" can bypass that check.

column2: Path Traversal: 'dir\..\..\filename'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize 'dir\..\..\filename' (multiple internal backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The 'dir\..\..\filename' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. Sometimes a program only removes one "..\" sequence
column6: so multiple "..\" can bypass that check. Alternately
column7: this manipulation could be used to bypass a check for "..\" at the beginning of the pathname
column8: moving up more than one directory level.

column2: Path Traversal: '...' (Triple Dot)
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize '...' (triple dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The '...' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. On some Windows systems
column6: it is equivalent to "..\.." and might bypass checks that assume only two dots are valid. Incomplete filtering
column7: such as removal of "./" sequences
column8: can ultimately produce valid ".." sequences due to a collapse into unsafe value (CWE-182).

column2: Path Traversal: '....' (Multiple Dot)
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize '....' (multiple dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The '....' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. On some Windows systems
column6: it is equivalent to "..\..\.." and might bypass checks that assume only two dots are valid. Incomplete filtering
column7: such as removal of "./" sequences
column8: can ultimately produce valid ".." sequences due to a collapse into unsafe value (CWE-182).

column2: Path Traversal: '....//'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize '....//' (doubled dot dot slash) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The '....//' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. If "../" is filtered in a sequential fashion
column6: as done by some regular expression engines
column7: then "....//" can collapse into the "../" unsafe value (CWE-182). It could also be useful when ".." is removed
column8: if the operating system treats "//" and "/" as equivalent.

column2: Path Traversal: '.../...//'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize '.../...//' (doubled triple dot slash) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The '.../...//' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. If "../" is filtered in a sequential fashion
column6: as done by some regular expression engines
column7: then ".../...//" can collapse into the "../" unsafe value (CWE-182). Removing the first "../" yields "....//"; the second removal yields "../". Depending on the algorithm
column8: the product could be susceptible to CWE-34 but not CWE-35

column2: Absolute Path Traversal
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize absolute path sequences such as "/abs/path" that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.

column2: Path Traversal: '/absolute/pathname/here'
column4: The product accepts input in the form of a slash absolute path ('/absolute/pathname/here') without appropriate validation
column5: which can allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

column2: Path Traversal: '\absolute\pathname\here'
column4: The product accepts input in the form of a backslash absolute path ('\absolute\pathname\here') without appropriate validation
column5: which can allow an attacker to traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files.

column2: Path Traversal: 'C:dirname'
column4: The product accepts input that contains a drive letter or Windows volume letter ('C:dirname') that potentially redirects access to an unintended location or arbitrary file.

column2: Path Traversal: '\\UNC\share\name\' (Windows UNC Share)
column4: The product accepts input that identifies a Windows UNC share ('\\UNC\share\name') that potentially redirects access to an unintended location or arbitrary file.

column2: Passing Mutable Objects to an Untrusted Method
column4: The product sends non-cloned mutable data as an argument to a method or function. The function or method that has been called can alter or delete the mutable data. This could violate assumptions that the calling function has made about its state. In situations where unknown code is called with references to mutable data
column5: this external code could make changes to the data sent. If this data was not previously cloned
column6: the modified data might not be valid in the context of execution.

column2: Returning a Mutable Object to an Untrusted Caller
column4: Sending non-cloned mutable data as a return value may result in that data being altered or deleted by the calling function. In situations where functions return references to mutable data
column5: it is possible that the external code which called the function may make changes to the data sent. If this data was not previously cloned
column6: the class will then be using modified data which may violate assumptions about its internal state.

column2: Insecure Temporary File
column4: Creating and using insecure temporary files can leave application and system data vulnerable to attack.

column2: Creation of Temporary File With Insecure Permissions

column2: Use of Implicit Intent for Sensitive Communication

column5: any application can process the intent by using an Intent Filter for that intent. This can allow untrusted applications to obtain sensitive data. There are two variations on the standard broadcast intent
column6: ordered and sticky. Ordered broadcast intents are delivered to a series of registered receivers in order of priority as declared by the Receivers. A malicious receiver can give itself a high priority and cause a denial of service by stopping the broadcast from propagating further down the chain. There is also the possibility of malicious data modification
column7: as a receiver may also alter the data within the Intent before passing it on to the next receiver. The downstream components have no way of asserting that the data has not been altered earlier in the chain. Sticky broadcast intents remain accessible after the initial broadcast. An old sticky intent will be broadcast again to any new receivers that register for it in the future
column8: greatly increasing the chances of information exposure over time. Also
column9: sticky broadcasts cannot be protected by permissions that may apply to other kinds of intents. In addition
column10: any broadcast intent may include a URI that references data that the receiving component does not normally have the privileges to access. The sender of the intent can include special privileges that grant the receiver read or write access to the specific URI included in the intent. A malicious receiver that intercepts this intent will also gain those privileges and be able to read or write the resource at the specified URI.

column2: Improper Zeroization of Hardware Register

column12: or if the user of the hardware block changes. The process of clearing register contents in a hardware IP is referred to as zeroization in standards for cryptographic hardware modules such as FIPS-140-2 [REF-267].

column2: Insufficient or Incomplete Data Removal within Hardware Component

column2: Remanent Data Readable after Memory Erase
column4: Confidential information stored in memory circuits is readable or recoverable after being cleared or erased. Data remanence occurs when stored
column5: memory content is not fully lost after a memory-clear or -erase operation. Confidential memory contents can still be readable through data remanence in the hardware. Data remanence can occur because of performance optimization or memory organization during 'clear' or 'erase' operations

column7: file pointers) to be erased without erasing the actual memory content. To protect against this weakness
column8: memory devices will often support different commands for optimized memory erase and explicit secure erase. Data remanence can also happen because of the physical properties of memory circuits in use. For example
column11: random-access-memory (DRAM) data retention is based on the charge retained in the memory cell
column12: which depends on factors such as power supply
column14: and temperature. Other than explicit erase commands

column17: only the decryption keys for encrypted data stored on the device are erased. That is
column18: the stored data are always remnant in the media after a cryptographic erase. However

column20: protection against data recovery in such designs relies on the strength of the encryption algorithm.

column7: or microcode assist results in a flush operation to clear results that are no longer required. This action prevents these results from influencing architectural state that is intended to be visible from software. However
column8: traces of this transient execution may remain in microarchitectural buffers
column9: resulting in a change in microarchitectural state that can expose sensitive information to an attacker using side-channel analysis. For example
column10: Load Value Injection (LVI) [REF-1202] can exploit direct injection of erroneous values into intermediate load and store buffers. Several conditions may need to be fulfilled for a successful attack: 1) incorrect transient execution that results in remanence of sensitive information; 2) attacker has the ability to provoke microarchitectural exceptions; 3) operations and structures in victim code that can be exploited must be identified.

column2: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type
column4: The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

column2: Download of Code Without Integrity Check
column4: The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server
column5: performing DNS spoofing
column6: or modifying the code in transit.

column2: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere
column4: The product imports
column5: requires
column6: or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere. When including third-party functionality
column7: such as a web widget
column10: the product must effectively trust that functionality. Without sufficient protection mechanisms
column11: the functionality could be malicious in nature (either by coming from an untrusted source
column13: or being modified in transit from a trusted source). The functionality might also contain its own weaknesses
column14: or grant access to additional functionality and state information that should be kept private to the base system
column17: or the DOM of a web application. This might lead to many different consequences depending on the included functionality
column18: but some examples include injection of malware
column19: information exposure by granting excessive privileges or permissions to the untrusted functionality

column2: Inclusion of Web Functionality from an Untrusted Source
column4: The product includes web functionality (such as a web widget) from another domain
column5: which causes it to operate within the domain of the product
column6: potentially granting total access and control of the product to the untrusted source. Including third party functionality in a web-based environment is risky
column7: especially if the source of the functionality is untrusted. Even if the third party is a trusted source
column8: the product may still be exposed to attacks and malicious behavior if that trusted source is compromised
column9: or if the code is modified in transmission from the third party to the product. This weakness is common in "mashup" development on the web
column10: which may include source functionality from other domains. For example
column11: Javascript-based web widgets may be inserted by using '<SCRIPT SRC="http://other.domain.here">' tags
column12: which causes the code to run in the domain of the product
column13: not the remote site from which the widget was loaded. As a result
column14: the included code has access to the local DOM
column15: including cookies and other data that the developer might not want the remote site to be able to access. Such dependencies may be desirable
column17: but sometimes programmers are not aware that a dependency exists.

column2: External Influence of Sphere Definition
column4: The product does not prevent the definition of control spheres from external actors. Typically
column5: a product defines its control sphere within the code itself
column6: or through configuration by the product's administrator. In some cases
column7: an external party can change the definition of the control sphere. This is typically a resultant weakness.

column2: Untrusted Search Path
column4: The product searches for critical resources using an externally-supplied search path that can point to resources that are not under the product's direct control. This might allow attackers to execute their own programs
column5: access unauthorized data files
column6: or modify configuration in unexpected ways. If the product uses a search path to locate critical resources such as programs
column7: then an attacker could modify that search path to point to a malicious program
column8: which the targeted product would then execute. The problem extends to any type of critical resource that the product trusts. Some of the most common variants of untrusted search path are: In various UNIX and Linux-based systems
column9: the PATH environment variable may be consulted to locate executable programs
column10: and LD_PRELOAD may be used to locate a separate library. In various Microsoft-based systems
column11: the PATH environment variable is consulted to locate a DLL
column12: if the DLL is not found in other paths that appear earlier in the search order.

column2: Incorrect Type Conversion or Cast
column4: The product does not correctly convert an object
column5: resource
column6: or structure from one type to a different type.

column2: Incorrect Parsing of Numbers with Different Radices
column4: The product parses numeric input assuming base 10 (decimal) values
column5: but it does not account for inputs that use a different base number (radix). Frequently
column6: a numeric input that begins with "0" is treated as octal
column7: or "0x" causes it to be treated as hexadecimal
column8: e.g. by the inet_addr() function. For example
column10: or "0x31" is 49 decimal. Other bases may be used as well. If the developer assumes decimal-only inputs
column11: the code could produce incorrect numbers when the inputs are parsed using a different base. This can result in unexpected and/or dangerous behavior. For example
column12: a "0127.0.0.1" IP address is parsed as octal due to the leading "0"
column13: whose numeric value would be the same as 87.0.0.1 (decimal)
column14: where the developer likely expected to use 127.0.0.1. The consequences vary depending on the surrounding code in which this weakness occurs
column15: but they can include bypassing network-based access control using unexpected IP addresses or netmasks
column16: or causing apparently-symbolic identifiers to be processed as if they are numbers. In web applications
column17: this can enable bypassing of SSRF restrictions.

column2: Attempt to Access Child of a Non-structure Pointer
column4: Casting a non-structure type to a structure type and accessing a field can lead to memory access errors or data corruption.

column2: Incorrect Conversion between Numeric Types
column4: When converting from one data type to another
column5: such as long to integer
column6: data can be omitted or translated in a way that produces unexpected values. If the resulting values are used in a sensitive context
column7: then dangerous behaviors may occur.

column2: Integer Coercion Error
column4: Integer coercion refers to a set of flaws pertaining to the type casting
column5: extension
column6: or truncation of primitive data types. Several flaws fall under the category of integer coercion errors. For the most part
column7: these errors in and of themselves result only in availability and data integrity issues. However

column2: Numeric Truncation Error
column4: Truncation errors occur when a primitive is cast to a primitive of a smaller size and data is lost in the conversion. When a primitive is cast to a smaller primitive
column5: the high order bits of the large value are lost in the conversion
column6: potentially resulting in an unexpected value that is not equal to the original value. This value may be required as an index into a buffer
column7: a loop iterator
column8: or simply necessary state data. In any case
column9: the value cannot be trusted and the system will be in an undefined state. While this method may be employed viably to isolate the low bits of a value
column11: and truncation usually implies that an implementation error has occurred.

column2: Use of Incorrectly-Resolved Name or Reference
column4: The product uses a name or reference to access a resource
column5: but the name/reference resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

column2: Improper Handling of Case Sensitivity
column4: The product does not properly account for differences in case sensitivity when accessing or determining the properties of a resource
column5: leading to inconsistent results. Improperly handled case sensitive data can lead to several possible consequences
column6: including: case-insensitive passwords reducing the size of the key space
column7: making brute force attacks easier bypassing filters or access controls using alternate names multiple interpretation errors using alternate names.

column2: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory
column5: but the product does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory. Many file operations are intended to take place within a restricted directory. By using special elements such as ".." and "/" separators
column6: attackers can escape outside of the restricted location to access files or directories that are elsewhere on the system. One of the most common special elements is the "../" sequence
column7: which in most modern operating systems is interpreted as the parent directory of the current location. This is referred to as relative path traversal. Path traversal also covers the use of absolute pathnames such as "/usr/local/bin"
column8: which may also be useful in accessing unexpected files. This is referred to as absolute path traversal. In many programming languages
column9: the injection of a null byte (the 0 or NUL) may allow an attacker to truncate a generated filename to widen the scope of attack. For example
column10: the product may add ".txt" to any pathname
column11: thus limiting the attacker to text files
column12: but a null injection may effectively remove this restriction.

column2: Relative Path Traversal
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize sequences such as ".." that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory.

column2: Path Traversal: '../filedir'
column4: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory
column5: but it does not properly neutralize "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The "../" manipulation is the canonical manipulation for operating systems that use "/" as directory separators
column6: such as UNIX- and Linux-based systems. In some cases
column7: it is useful for bypassing protection schemes in environments for which "/" is supported but not the primary separator
column9: which uses "\" but can also accept "/".

column2: Path Traversal: '/../filedir'

column5: but it does not properly neutralize "/../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. Sometimes a program checks for "../" at the beginning of the input
column6: so a "/../" can bypass that check.

column2: Path Traversal: '/dir/../filename'

column5: but it does not properly neutralize "/dir/../filename" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The '/dir/../filename' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. Sometimes a program only checks for "../" at the beginning of the input
column6: so a "/../" can bypass that check.

column2: Path Traversal: 'dir/../../filename'

column5: but it does not properly neutralize multiple internal "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. The 'directory/../../filename' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. Sometimes a program only removes one "../" sequence
column6: so multiple "../" can bypass that check. Alternately
column7: this manipulation could be used to bypass a check for "../" at the beginning of the pathname
column8: moving up more than one directory level.

column6: such as Windows. However
column7: it is also useful for bypassing path traversal protection schemes that only assume that the "/" separator is valid.

column5: but it does not properly neutralize '\..\filename' (leading backslash dot dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. This is similar to CWE-25
column6: except using "\" instead of "/". Sometimes a program checks for "..\" at the beginning of the input

This allows attackers to traverse the file system to access files or directories that are outside of the restricted directory. column5: but it does not properly neutralize '...' (triple dot) sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. The '...' manipulation is useful for bypassing some path traversal protection schemes. On some Windows systems
column6: it is equivalent to "..\.." and might bypass checks that assume only two dots are valid. Incomplete filtering
column7: such as removal of "./" sequences

column6: it is equivalent to "..\..\.." and might bypass checks that assume only two dots are valid. Incomplete filtering

column12: called a mount point. If a file is used by a privileged program
column13: but it can be replaced with a hard link to a sensitive file (e.g.
column15: an attacker could excalate privileges. When the process opens the file

column2: UNIX Symbolic Link (Symlink) Following
column4: The product
column5: when opening a file or directory
column6: does not sufficiently account for when the file is a symbolic link that resolves to a target outside of the intended control sphere. The symbolic link can permit an attacker to read/write/corrupt a file that they originally did not have permissions to access.

column7: an attacker can escalate their privileges if a file used by a privileged program is replaced with a hard link to a sensitive file (e.g. /etc/passwd). When the process opens the file

column6: CON

column9: LPT1) can result in different types of vulnerabilities. In some cases an attacker can request a device via injection of a virtual filename in a URL

column5: or detect usage of
column6: alternate data streams (ADS). An attacker can use an ADS to hide information about a file (e.g. size

column4: The product does not properly handle special paths that may identify the data or resource fork of a file on the HFS+ file system. If the product chooses actions to take based on the file name
column5: then if an attacker provides the data or resource fork
column6: the product may take unexpected actions. Further

column2: Improper Update of Reference Count
column4: The product uses a reference count to manage a resource
column5: but it does not update or incorrectly updates the reference count. Reference counts can be used when tracking how many objects contain a reference to a particular resource
column6: such as in memory management or garbage collection. When the reference count reaches zero
column7: the resource can be de-allocated or reused because there are no more objects that use it. If the reference count accidentally reaches zero
column8: then the resource might be released too soon
column9: even though it is still in use. If all objects no longer use the resource
column10: but the reference count is not zero
column11: then the resource might not ever be released.

column2: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources
column4: The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables
column5: objects
column6: classes
column7: attributes
column9: or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code
column10: or resources used by code such as variables and objects. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time

or series of instances and method invocations that can self-execute during the deserialization process (i.e., before the object is returned to the caller), it is sometimes possible for attackers to leverage them to perform unauthorized actions, like generating a shell.,[CVE-2019-12799, CVE-2015-8103, CVE-2015-4852, CVE-2013-1465, CVE-2012-3527, CVE-2012-0911, CVE-2012-0911, CVE-2011-2520, CVE-2012-4406, CVE-2003-0791]
914,Improper Control of Dynamically-Identified Variables,,The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-identified variables. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to access arbitrary variables that are specified by an input string. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can modify unintended variables that have security implications.,[CVE-2006-7135, CVE-2006-7079, CVE-2007-0649, CVE-2006-6661, CVE-2006-2828, CVE-2009-0422, CVE-2007-2431, CVE-2006-4904, CVE-2006-4019]
915,Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes,Not Language-Specific,The product receives input from an upstream component that specifies multiple attributes, properties, or fields that are to be initialized or updated in an object, but it does not properly control which attributes can be modified. If the object contains attributes that were only intended for internal use, then their unexpected modification could lead to a vulnerability. This weakness is sometimes known by the language-specific mechanisms that make it possible, such as mass assignment, autobinding, or object injection.,[CVE-2012-2054, CVE-2012-2055, CVE-2008-7310, CVE-2013-1465, CVE-2012-3527, CVE-2012-0911, CVE-2012-0911, CVE-2011-4962, CVE-2009-4137, CVE-2007-5741, CVE-2011-2520, CVE-2005-2875, CVE-2013-0277, CVE-2011-2894, CVE-2012-1833, CVE-2010-3258, CVE-2008-1013]
1321,Improperly Controlled Modification of Object Prototype Attributes ('Prototype Pollution'),Java,The product receives input from an upstream component that specifies attributes that are to be initialized or updated in an object, but it does not properly control modifications of attributes of the object prototype. By adding or modifying attributes of an object prototype, it is possible to create attributes that exist on every object, or replace critical attributes with malicious ones. This can be problematic if the product depends on existence or non-existence of certain attributes, or uses pre-defined attributes of object prototype (such as hasOwnProperty, toString or valueOf). This weakness is usually exploited by using a special attribute of objects called proto, constructor or prototype. Such attributes give access to the object prototype. This weakness is often found in code that assigns object attributes based on user input, or merges or clones objects recursively.,[CVE-2018-3721, CVE-2019-10744, CVE-2019-11358, CVE-2020-8203]
1336,Improper Neutralization of Special Elements Used in a Template Engine,Java,The product uses a template engine to insert or process externally-influenced input, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements or syntax that can be interpreted as template expressions or other code directives when processed by the engine. Many web applications use template engines that allow developers to insert externally-influenced values into free text or messages in order to generate a full web page, document, message, etc. Such engines include Twig, Jinja2, Pug, Java Server Pages, FreeMarker, Velocity, ColdFusion, Smarty, and many others - including PHP itself. Some CMS (Content Management Systems) also use templates. Template engines often have their own custom command or expression language. If an attacker can influence input into a template before it is processed, then the attacker can invoke arbitrary expressions, i.e. perform injection attacks. For example, in some template languages, an attacker could inject the expression {{7*7}}" and determine if the output returns "49" instead. The syntax varies depending on the language. In some cases
column9: which can obscure the root cause if the developer does not closely investigate the root cause of the error. Template engines can be used on the server or client

column2: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition')
column4: The product contains a code sequence that can run concurrently with other code
column5: and the code sequence requires temporary
column6: exclusive access to a shared resource
column7: but a timing window exists in which the shared resource can be modified by another code sequence that is operating concurrently. This can have security implications when the expected synchronization is in security-critical code
column8: such as recording whether a user is authenticated or modifying important state information that should not be influenced by an outsider. A race condition occurs within concurrent environments
column9: and is effectively a property of a code sequence. Depending on the context
column10: a code sequence may be in the form of a function call
column13: etc. A race condition violates these properties
column14: which are closely related: Exclusivity - the code sequence is given exclusive access to the shared resource
column16: no other code sequence can modify properties of the shared resource before the original sequence has completed execution. Atomicity - the code sequence is behaviorally atomic
column18: no other thread or process can concurrently execute the same sequence of instructions (or a subset) against the same resource. A race condition exists when an "interfering code sequence" can still access the shared resource
column19: violating exclusivity. Programmers may assume that certain code sequences execute too quickly to be affected by an interfering code sequence; when they are not
column21: the single "x++" statement may appear atomic at the code layer
column22: but it is actually non-atomic at the instruction layer
column23: since it involves a read (the original value of x)
column25: followed by a write (save the result to x). The interfering code sequence could be "trusted" or "untrusted." A trusted interfering code sequence occurs within the product; it cannot be modified by the attacker
column26: and it can only be invoked indirectly. An untrusted interfering code sequence can be authored directly by the attacker
column27: and typically it is external to the vulnerable product.

column4: The product does not properly acquire or release a lock on a resource

Locking is a type of synchronization behavior that ensures that multiple independently-operating processes or threads do not interfere with each other when accessing the same resource. All processes/threads are expected to follow the same steps for locking. If these steps are not followed precisely - or if no locking is done at all - then another process/thread could modify the shared resource in a way that is not visible or predictable to the original process. This can lead to data or memory corruption
column6: denial of service
column7: etc.

column4: The product utilizes a shared resource in a concurrent manner

column5: but there is no timeout for the call

column2: Hardware Logic with Insecure De-Synchronization between Control and Data Channels
column4: The hardware logic for error handling and security checks can incorrectly forward data before the security check is complete. Many high-performance on-chip bus protocols and processor data-paths employ separate channels for control and data to increase parallelism and maximize throughput. Bugs in the hardware logic that handle errors and security checks can make it possible for data to be forwarded before the completion of the security checks. If the data can propagate to a location in the hardware observable to an attacker
column5: loss of data confidentiality can occur. 'Meltdown' is a concrete example of how de-synchronization between data and permissions checking logic can violate confidentiality requirements. Data loaded from a page marked as privileged was returned to the cpu regardless of current privilege level for performance reasons. The assumption was that the cpu could later remove all traces of this data during the handling of the illegal memory access exception
column6: but this assumption was proven false as traces of the secret data were not removed from the microarchitectural state.

column2: Call to Thread run() instead of start()

column5: which causes the code to run in the thread of the caller instead of the callee. In most cases a direct call to a Thread object's run() method is a bug. The programmer intended to begin a new thread of control
column6: but accidentally called run() instead of start()
column7: so the run() method will execute in the caller's thread of control.

column2: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Synchronization Primitives
column4: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using thread synchronization primitives. The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case
column5: the product violates the following EJB guideline: "An enterprise bean must not use thread synchronization primitives to synchronize execution of multiple instances." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "This rule is required to ensure consistent runtime semantics because while some EJB containers may use a single JVM to execute all enterprise bean's instances
column6: others may distribute the instances across multiple JVMs."

column2: Use of Incorrect Operator

column5: the if statement will usually evaluate the value of the right-hand side of the predicate.

column4: The web application sends a redirect to another location

column2: Incorrect Behavior Order

column2: Incorrect Behavior Order: Early Validation

column2: Uncaught Exception
column4: An exception is thrown from a function

column2: J2EE Bad Practices: Use of System.exit()
column4: A J2EE application uses System.exit()
column5: which also shuts down its container. It is never a good idea for a web application to attempt to shut down the application container. Access to a function that can shut down the application is an avenue for Denial of Service (DoS) attacks.

column2: Use of NullPointerException Catch to Detect NULL Pointer Dereference
column4: Catching NullPointerException should not be used as an alternative to programmatic checks to prevent dereferencing a null pointer. Programmers typically catch NullPointerException under three circumstances: The program contains a null pointer dereference. Catching the resulting exception was easier than fixing the underlying problem. The program explicitly throws a NullPointerException to signal an error condition. The code is part of a test harness that supplies unexpected input to the classes under test. Of these three circumstances
column5: only the last is acceptable.

column2: Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception

column5: but "condensing" catch blocks by catching a high-level class like Exception can obscure exceptions that deserve special treatment or that should not be caught at this point in the program. Catching an overly broad exception essentially defeats the purpose of Java's typed exceptions
column6: and can become particularly dangerous if the program grows and begins to throw new types of exceptions. The new exception types will not receive any attention.

column2: Declaration of Throws for Generic Exception
column4: Throwing overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities. Declaring a method to throw Exception or Throwable makes it difficult for callers to perform proper error handling and error recovery. Java's exception mechanism
column5: for example
column6: is set up to make it easy for callers to anticipate what can go wrong and write code to handle each specific exceptional circumstance. Declaring that a method throws a generic form of exception defeats this system.

column16: or other custom event loop code.

column4: The product does not properly control the amount of recursion that takes place

column6: such as allocated memory or the program stack.

column4: The product contains an iteration or loop with an exit condition that cannot be reached
column5: i.e.
column6: an infinite loop. If the loop can be influenced by an attacker

An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example

column7: and
column9: it indicates a logic 1. Fuses are generally considered to be one-directional

column5: viewed at high enough magnification
column6: can reveal the information stored inside. Typical steps in IC reverse engineering involve removing the chip packaging (decapsulation) then using various imaging techniques ranging from high resolution x-ray microscopy to invasive techniques involving removing IC layers and imaging each layer using a scanning electron microscope. The goal of such activities is to recover secret keys
column7: unique device identifiers
column8: and proprietary code and circuit designs embedded in hardware that the attacker has been unsuccessful at accessing through other means. These secrets may be stored in non-volatile memory or in the circuit netlist. Memory technologies such as masked ROM allow easier to extraction of secrets than One-time Programmable (OTP) memory.

column2: Public Key Re-Use for Signing both Debug and Production Code
column4: The same public key is used for signing both debug and production code. A common usage of public-key cryptography is to verify the integrity and authenticity of another entity (for example a firmware binary). If a company wants to ensure that its firmware runs only on its own hardware
column5: before the firmware runs
column6: an encrypted hash of the firmware image will be decrypted with the public key and then verified against the now-computed hash of the firmware image. This means that the public key forms the root of trust
column7: which necessitates that the public key itself must be protected and used properly. During the development phase
column8: debug firmware enables many hardware debug hooks
column10: and debug messages for testing. Those debug facilities provide significant
column11: additional views about the firmware's capability and
column13: additional capability into the chip or SoC. If compromised
column14: these capabilities could be exploited by an attacker to take full control of the system. Once the product exits the manufacturing stage and enters production
column15: it is good practice to use a different public key. Debug firmware images are known to leak. With the debug key being reused as the production key
column16: the debug image will also work on the production image. Thus
column17: it will open all the internal
column18: debug capabilities to the attacker. If a different public key is used for the production image

column20: they will not be able to run it on a production machine. Thus
column21: damage will be limited to the intellectual property leakage resulting from the debug image.

column4: On-chip fabrics or buses either do not support or are not configured to support privilege separation or other security features
column5: such as access control. Certain on-chip fabrics and buses
column6: especially simple and low-power buses
column7: do not support security features. Apart from data transfer and addressing ports
column8: some fabrics and buses do not have any interfaces to transfer privilege
column10: or any other security attribute coming from the bus master. Similarly
column11: they do not have dedicated signals to transport security-sensitive data from slave to master
column12: such as completions for certain types of transactions. Few other on-chip fabrics and buses support security features and define specific interfaces/signals for transporting security attributes from master to slave or vice-versa. However
column13: including these signals is not mandatory and could be left unconfigured when generating the register-transfer-level (RTL) description for the fabric. Such fabrics or buses should not be used to transport any security attribute coming from the bus master. In general

column5: causing device internal information to be compromised or security mechanisms to be bypassed. Electromagnetic fault injection may allow an attacker to locally and dynamically modify the signals (both internal and external) of an integrated circuit. EM-FI attacks consist of producing a local
column6: transient magnetic field near the device
column7: inducing current in the device wires. A typical EMFI setup is made up of a pulse injection circuit that generates a high current transient in an EMI coil
column8: producing an abrupt magnetic pulse which couples to the target producing faults in the device
column9: which can lead to: Bypassing security mechanisms such as secure JTAG or Secure Boot Leaking device information Modifying program flow Perturbing secure hardware modules (e.g. random number generators)

These data play a crucial role in establishing a Root of Trust (RoT) to execute secure-boot flows. One of the many ways RoT is achieved is by storing the code and data in memory or fuses. This memory should be immutable
column6: i.e.
column7: once the RoT is programmed/provisioned in memory
column8: that memory should be locked and prevented from further programming or writes. If the memory contents (i.e.
column10: then an adversary can modify the RoT to execute their choice of code

column13: secure patching/update features should be supported to allow authenticated and authorized updates in the field.

column2: Improper Protections Against Hardware Overheating

column6: and semiconductor silicon have thermal side effects

column9: higher-operating frequency of silicon results in higher power dissipation and heat. The leakage current in CMOS circuits increases with temperature
column10: and this creates positive feedback that can result in thermal runaway and damage the device permanently. Any device lacking protections such as thermal sensors

column16: because the hardware product is expected to work for years

column29: and government entities looking for any possible flaws. Furthermore

column2: Generation of Weak Initialization Vector (IV)

column2: Generation of Predictable IV with CBC Mode

column5: which causes algorithms to be susceptible to dictionary attacks when they are encrypted under the same key. CBC mode eliminates a weakness of Electronic Code Book (ECB) mode by allowing identical plaintext blocks to be encrypted to different ciphertext blocks. This is possible by the XOR-ing of an IV with the initial plaintext block so that every plaintext block in the chain is XOR'd with a different value before encryption. If IVs are reused
column6: then identical plaintexts would be encrypted to identical ciphertexts. However
column7: even if IVs are not identical but are predictable
column8: then they still break the security of CBC mode against Chosen Plaintext Attacks (CPA).

column5: or used by

column2: Improper Handling of Insufficient Entropy in TRNG
column4: True random number generators (TRNG) generally have a limited source of entropy and therefore can fail or block. The rate at which true random numbers can be generated is limited. It is important that one uses them only when they are needed for security.

column2: Small Space of Random Values

column5: making it more susceptible to brute force attacks.
