column5: then they may be able to take over the user's session (called session hijacking). The number of possible session IDs increases with increased session ID length
column6: making it more difficult to guess or steal a session ID.

column2: Incorrect Usage of Seeds in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)
column4: The product uses a Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG) but does not correctly manage seeds. PRNGs are deterministic and
column5: while their output appears random
column6: they cannot actually create entropy. They rely on cryptographically secure and unique seeds for entropy so proper seeding is critical to the secure operation of the PRNG. Management of seeds could be broken down into two main areas: (1) protecting seeds as cryptographic material (such as a cryptographic key); (2) whenever possible
column7: using a uniquely generated seed from a cryptographically secure source PRNGs require a seed as input to generate a stream of numbers that are functionally indistinguishable from random numbers. While the output is
column10: the output of any PRNG is directly determined by the seed provided as input. If the seed can be ascertained by a third party
column11: the entire output of the PRNG can be made known to them. As such
column12: the seed should be kept secret and should ideally not be able to be guessed. For example
column13: the current time may be a poor seed. Knowing the approximate time the PRNG was seeded greatly reduces the possible key space. Seeds do not necessarily need to be unique
column14: but reusing seeds may open up attacks if the seed is discovered.

column2: Same Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)

column5: using the same seed for each initialization will lead to the same output in the same order. If an attacker can guess (or knows) the seed
column6: then the attacker may be able to determine the random numbers that will be produced from the PRNG.

column2: Predictable Seed in Pseudo-Random Number Generator (PRNG)

column5: such as the process ID or system time. The use of predictable seeds significantly reduces the number of possible seeds that an attacker would need to test in order to predict which random numbers will be generated by the PRNG.

column2: Small Seed Space in PRNG

column5: which makes it more susceptible to brute force attacks. PRNGs are entirely deterministic once seeded
column6: so it should be extremely difficult to guess the seed. If an attacker can collect the outputs of a PRNG and then brute force the seed by trying every possibility to see which seed matches the observed output
column7: then the attacker will know the output of any subsequent calls to the PRNG. A small seed space implies that the attacker will have far fewer possible values to try to exhaust all possibilities.

column7: finite

column2: Missing Source Correlation of Multiple Independent Data
column4: The product relies on one source of data

column2: Origin Validation Error

column6: as the channel will remain open until the client or the server is ready to send the message
column7: whereas in HTTP
column8: once the response occurs (which typically happens immediately)
column9: the transaction completes. A WebSocket can leverage the existing HTTP protocol over ports 80 and 443
column10: but it is not limited to HTTP. WebSockets can make cross-origin requests that are not restricted by browser-based protection mechanisms such as the Same Origin Policy (SOP) or Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS). Without explicit origin validation
column11: this makes CSRF attacks more powerful.

column4: The product does not verify

column5: but it uses the source that has less support for verification

column2: Acceptance of Extraneous Untrusted Data With Trusted Data
column4: The product
column5: when processing trusted data

column7: treating the untrusted data as if it were trusted.

column2: Insufficient Type Distinction
column4: The product does not properly distinguish between different types of elements in a way that leads to insecure behavior.

column2: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
column4: The web application does not
column5: or can not
column6: sufficiently verify whether a well-formed
column7: valid
column8: consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent
column9: then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL
column12: etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

column2: Missing Support for Integrity Check
column4: The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission
column5: such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol
column6: there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications
column7: the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum
column8: since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages

column2: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value
column4: The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or "checksums" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission. Improper validation of checksums before use results in an unnecessary risk that can easily be mitigated. The protocol specification describes the algorithm used for calculating the checksum. It is then a simple matter of implementing the calculation and verifying that the calculated checksum and the received checksum match. Improper verification of the calculated checksum and the received checksum can lead to far greater consequences.

column2: Trust of System Event Data
column4: Security based on event locations are insecure and can be spoofed. Events are a messaging system which may provide control data to programs listening for events. Events often do not have any type of authentication framework to allow them to be verified from a trusted source. Any application
column5: in Windows
column6: on a given desktop can send a message to any window on the same desktop. There is no authentication framework for these messages. Therefore
column7: any message can be used to manipulate any process on the desktop if the process does not check the validity and safeness of those messages.

column2: Unprotected Windows Messaging Channel ('Shatter')
column4: The product does not properly verify the source of a message in the Windows Messaging System while running at elevated privileges
column5: creating an alternate channel through which an attacker can directly send a message to the product.
column11: Attacker uses Shatter attack to bypass GUI-enforced protection for CVE-2003-0908.

column2: Download of Code Without Integrity Check

column6: or modifying the code in transit.

column7: deciding what data should be made available

column9: then the wrong action could occur. For example
column10: an attacker could supply a file that ends in a ".php.gif" extension that appears to be a GIF image
column11: but would be processed as PHP code. In extreme cases
column13: but the attacker could also cause exhaustion of resources
column15: exposure of debug or system data (including application source code)
column16: or being bound to a particular server side process. This weakness may be due to a vulnerability in any of the technologies used by the web and application servers
column18: or resultant from another flaw in the application itself.

column2: Reliance on Obfuscation or Encryption of Security-Relevant Inputs without Integrity Checking
column4: The product uses obfuscation or encryption of inputs that should not be mutable by an external actor
column5: but the product does not use integrity checks to detect if those inputs have been modified. When an application relies on obfuscation or incorrectly applied / weak encryption to protect client-controllable tokens or parameters
column6: that may have an effect on the user state
column7: system state
column8: or some decision made on the server. Without protecting the tokens/parameters for integrity
column9: the application is vulnerable to an attack where an adversary traverses the space of possible values of the said token/parameter in order to attempt to gain an advantage. The goal of the attacker is to find another admissible value that will somehow elevate their privileges in the system
column10: disclose information or change the behavior of the system in some way beneficial to the attacker. If the application does not protect these critical tokens/parameters for integrity
column11: it will not be able to determine that these values have been tampered with. Measures that are used to protect data for confidentiality should not be relied upon to provide the integrity service.

column2: Improper Enforcement of Message Integrity During Transmission in a Communication Channel
column4: The product establishes a communication channel with an endpoint and receives a message from that endpoint
column5: but it does not sufficiently ensure that the message was not modified during transmission. Attackers might be able to modify the message and spoof the endpoint by interfering with the data as it crosses the network or by redirecting the connection to a system under their control.

column2: Insufficient UI Warning of Dangerous Operations
column4: The user interface provides a warning to a user regarding dangerous or sensitive operations
column5: but the warning is not noticeable enough to warrant attention.

column2: Multiple Interpretations of UI Input
column4: The UI has multiple interpretations of user input but does not prompt the user when it selects the less secure interpretation.

column2: Improperly Implemented Security Check for Standard
column4: The product does not implement or incorrectly implements one or more security-relevant checks as specified by the design of a standardized algorithm
column5: protocol
column6: or technique.

column2: Improper Protection of Alternate Path
column4: The product does not sufficiently protect all possible paths that a user can take to access restricted functionality or resources.

column2: Direct Request ('Forced Browsing')
column4: The web application does not adequately enforce appropriate authorization on all restricted URLs
column5: scripts
column6: or files. Web applications susceptible to direct request attacks often make the false assumption that such resources can only be reached through a given navigation path and so only apply authorization at certain points in the path.

column2: Client-Side Enforcement of Server-Side Security
column4: The product is composed of a server that relies on the client to implement a mechanism that is intended to protect the server. When the server relies on protection mechanisms placed on the client side
column5: an attacker can modify the client-side behavior to bypass the protection mechanisms
column6: resulting in potentially unexpected interactions between the client and server. The consequences will vary
column7: depending on what the mechanisms are trying to protect.

column2: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking
column4: The product relies on the existence or values of cookies when performing security-critical operations
column5: but it does not properly ensure that the setting is valid for the associated user. Attackers can easily modify cookies
column6: within the browser or by implementing the client-side code outside of the browser. Reliance on cookies without detailed validation and integrity checking can allow attackers to bypass authentication
column7: conduct injection attacks such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting
column8: or otherwise modify inputs in unexpected ways.

column2: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking in a Security Decision
column4: The product uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of a cookie
column5: but it does not properly ensure that the cookie is valid for the associated user. Attackers can easily modify cookies
column6: within the browser or by implementing the client-side code outside of the browser. Attackers can bypass protection mechanisms such as authorization and authentication by modifying the cookie to contain an expected value.

column2: Use of Client-Side Authentication
column4: A client/server product performs authentication within client code but not in server code
column5: allowing server-side authentication to be bypassed via a modified client that omits the authentication check. Client-side authentication is extremely weak and may be breached easily. Any attacker may read the source code and reverse-engineer the authentication mechanism to access parts of the application which would otherwise be protected.

column2: Improper Isolation or Compartmentalization
column4: The product does not properly compartmentalize or isolate functionality
column5: processes
column6: or resources that require different privilege levels
column7: rights
column8: or permissions. When a weakness occurs in functionality that is accessible by lower-privileged users
column10: an attack might extend the scope of the damage to higher-privileged users.

column2: Improper Isolation of Shared Resources on System-on-a-Chip (SoC)
column4: The System-On-a-Chip (SoC) does not properly isolate shared resources between trusted and untrusted agents. A System-On-a-Chip (SoC) has a lot of functionality
column5: but it may have a limited number of pins or pads. A pin can only perform one function at a time. However
column6: it can be configured to perform multiple different functions. This technique is called pin multiplexing. Similarly
column7: several resources on the chip may be shared to multiplex and support different features or functions. When such resources are shared between trusted and untrusted agents
column8: untrusted agents may be able to access the assets intended to be accessed only by the trusted agents.

column2: Non-Transparent Sharing of Microarchitectural Resources
column4: Hardware structures shared across execution contexts (e.g.
column5: caches and branch predictors) can violate the expected architecture isolation between contexts. Modern processors use techniques such as out-of-order execution
column6: speculation
column7: prefetching
column9: and caching to increase performance. Details about the implementation of these techniques are hidden from the programmer's view. This is problematic when the hardware implementation of these techniques results in resources being shared across supposedly isolated contexts. Contention for shared resources between different contexts opens covert channels that allow malicious programs executing in one context to recover information from another context. Some examples of shared micro-architectural resources that have been used to leak information between contexts are caches
column11: and load or store buffers. Speculative and out-of-order execution provides an attacker with increased control over which data is leaked through the covert channel. If the extent of resource sharing between contexts in the design microarchitecture is undocumented
column12: it is extremely difficult to ensure system assets are protected against disclosure.

column2: Improper Isolation of Shared Resources in Network On Chip (NoC)
column4: The Network On Chip (NoC) does not isolate or incorrectly isolates its on-chip-fabric and internal resources such that they are shared between trusted and untrusted agents
column5: creating timing channels. Typically
column6: network on chips (NoC) have many internal resources that are shared between packets from different trust domains. These resources include internal buffers
column7: crossbars and switches
column9: and channels. The sharing of resources causes contention and introduces interference between differently trusted domains
column10: which poses a security threat via a timing channel
column11: allowing attackers to infer data that belongs to a trusted agent. This may also result in introducing network interference
column12: resulting in degraded throughput and latency.

column2: Reliance on a Single Factor in a Security Decision
column4: A protection mechanism relies exclusively
column5: or to a large extent
column6: on the evaluation of a single condition or the integrity of a single object or entity in order to make a decision about granting access to restricted resources or functionality.

column2: Use of Single-factor Authentication
column4: The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication
column5: it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak
column6: reused
column7: and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes
column8: a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason
column9: if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use
column10: they should be implemented and required.

column2: Use of Password System for Primary Authentication
column4: The use of password systems as the primary means of authentication may be subject to several flaws or shortcomings
column5: each reducing the effectiveness of the mechanism.

column2: Insufficient Psychological Acceptability
column4: The product has a protection mechanism that is too difficult or inconvenient to use
column5: encouraging non-malicious users to disable or bypass the mechanism
column6: whether by accident or on purpose.

column2: Reliance on Security Through Obscurity
column4: The product uses a protection mechanism whose strength depends heavily on its obscurity
column5: such that knowledge of its algorithms or key data is sufficient to defeat the mechanism. This reliance on "security through obscurity" can produce resultant weaknesses if an attacker is able to reverse engineer the inner workings of the mechanism. Note that obscurity can be one small part of defense in depth
column6: since it can create more work for an attacker; however
column7: it is a significant risk if used as the primary means of protection.

column2: Selection of Less-Secure Algorithm During Negotiation ('Algorithm Downgrade')
column4: A protocol or its implementation supports interaction between multiple actors and allows those actors to negotiate which algorithm should be used as a protection mechanism such as encryption or authentication
column5: but it does not select the strongest algorithm that is available to both parties. When a security mechanism can be forced to downgrade to use a less secure algorithm
column6: this can make it easier for attackers to compromise the product by exploiting weaker algorithm. The victim might not be aware that the less secure algorithm is being used. For example
column7: if an attacker can force a communications channel to use cleartext instead of strongly-encrypted data
column8: then the attacker could read the channel by sniffing
column9: instead of going through extra effort of trying to decrypt the data using brute force techniques.

column2: Insufficient Logging
column4: When a security-critical event occurs
column5: the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it. When security-critical events are not logged properly
column6: such as a failed login attempt
column7: this can make malicious behavior more difficult to detect and may hinder forensic analysis after an attack succeeds. As organizations adopt cloud storage resources
column8: these technologies often require configuration changes to enable detailed logging information
column9: since detailed logging can incur additional costs. This could lead to telemetry gaps in critical audit logs. For example
column11: the default value for logging is disabled.

column2: Reliance on Untrusted Inputs in a Security Decision
column4: The product uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of an input
column5: but the input can be modified by an untrusted actor in a way that bypasses the protection mechanism. Developers may assume that inputs such as cookies
column6: environment variables
column7: and hidden form fields cannot be modified. However
column8: an attacker could change these inputs using customized clients or other attacks. This change might not be detected. When security decisions such as authentication and authorization are made based on the values of these inputs
column9: attackers can bypass the security of the software. Without sufficient encryption
column12: any input that originates from an outsider cannot be trusted.

column2: Authentication Bypass by Assumed-Immutable Data
column4: The authentication scheme or implementation uses key data elements that are assumed to be immutable
column5: but can be controlled or modified by the attacker.

column2: Reliance on Reverse DNS Resolution for a Security-Critical Action
column4: The product performs reverse DNS resolution on an IP address to obtain the hostname and make a security decision
column5: but it does not properly ensure that the IP address is truly associated with the hostname. Since DNS names can be easily spoofed or misreported
column6: and it may be difficult for the product to detect if a trusted DNS server has been compromised
column7: DNS names do not constitute a valid authentication mechanism. When the product performs a reverse DNS resolution for an IP address
column8: if an attacker controls the DNS server for that IP address
column9: then the attacker can cause the server to return an arbitrary hostname. As a result
column10: the attacker may be able to bypass authentication
column11: cause the wrong hostname to be recorded in log files to hide activities
column12: or perform other attacks. Attackers can spoof DNS names by either (1) compromising a DNS server and modifying its records (sometimes called DNS cache poisoning)
column13: or (2) having legitimate control over a DNS server associated with their IP address.

column2: Reliance on Cookies without Validation and Integrity Checking in a Security Decision
column4: The product uses a protection mechanism that relies on the existence or values of a cookie
column5: but it does not properly ensure that the cookie is valid for the associated user. Attackers can easily modify cookies
column6: within the browser or by implementing the client-side code outside of the browser. Attackers can bypass protection mechanisms such as authorization and authentication by modifying the cookie to contain an expected value.

column2: Incorrect Comparison
column4: The product compares two entities in a security-relevant context
column5: but the comparison is incorrect
column6: which may lead to resultant weaknesses. This Pillar covers several possibilities: the comparison checks one factor incorrectly; the comparison should consider multiple factors
column7: but it does not check at least one of those factors at all; the comparison checks the wrong factor.

column2: Incomplete Comparison with Missing Factors
column4: The product performs a comparison between entities that must consider multiple factors or characteristics of each entity
column5: but the comparison does not include one or more of these factors. An incomplete comparison can lead to resultant weaknesses
column6: e.g.
column7: by operating on the wrong object or making a security decision without considering a required factor.

column2: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs
column4: The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are not allowed by policy or otherwise require other action to neutralize before additional processing takes place
column5: but the list is incomplete
column6: leading to resultant weaknesses. Developers often try to protect their products against malicious input by performing tests against inputs that are known to be bad
column7: such as special characters that can invoke new commands. However
column8: such lists often only account for the most well-known bad inputs. Attackers may be able to find other malicious inputs that were not expected by the developer
column9: allowing them to bypass the intended protection mechanism.

column2: Partial String Comparison
column4: The product performs a comparison that only examines a portion of a factor before determining whether there is a match
column5: such as a substring
column6: leading to resultant weaknesses. For example
column7: an attacker might succeed in authentication by providing a small password that matches the associated portion of the larger

column2: Missing Default Case in Multiple Condition Expression
column4: The code does not have a default case in an expression with multiple conditions
column5: such as a switch statement. If a multiple-condition expression (such as a switch in C) omits the default case but does not consider or handle all possible values that could occur
column6: then this might lead to complex logical errors and resultant weaknesses. Because of this
column7: further decisions are made based on poor information
column8: and cascading failure results. This cascading failure may result in any number of security issues
column9: and constitutes a significant failure in the system.

column2: Comparison of Incompatible Types
column4: The product performs a comparison between two entities
column5: but the entities are of different
column6: incompatible types that cannot be guaranteed to provide correct results when they are directly compared. In languages that are strictly typed but support casting/conversion
column7: such as C or C++
column8: the programmer might assume that casting one entity to the same type as another entity will ensure that the comparison will be performed correctly
column9: but this cannot be guaranteed. In languages that are not strictly typed
column11: there may be implicit casting/conversion to a type that the programmer is unaware of
column13: the string "123" might be converted to a number type. See examples.

column2: Comparison Using Wrong Factors
column4: The code performs a comparison between two entities
column5: but the comparison examines the wrong factors or characteristics of the entities
column6: which can lead to incorrect results and resultant weaknesses. This can lead to incorrect results and resultant weaknesses. For example
column7: the code might inadvertently compare references to objects
column8: instead of the relevant contents of those objects
column9: causing two "equal" objects to be considered unequal.

column2: Comparison of Classes by Name
column4: The product compares classes by name
column5: which can cause it to use the wrong class when multiple classes can have the same name. If the decision to trust the methods and data of an object is based on the name of a class
column6: it is possible for malicious users to send objects of the same name as trusted classes and thereby gain the trust afforded to known classes and types.

column2: Comparison of Object References Instead of Object Contents
column4: The product compares object references instead of the contents of the objects themselves
column5: preventing it from detecting equivalent objects. For example
column6: in Java
column7: comparing objects using == usually produces deceptive results
column8: since the == operator compares object references rather than values; often
column9: this means that using == for strings is actually comparing the strings' references

column2: Use of Wrong Operator in String Comparison
column4: The product uses the wrong operator when comparing a string
column5: such as using "==" when the .equals() method should be used instead. In Java
column6: using == or != to compare two strings for equality actually compares two objects for equality rather than their string values for equality. Chances are good that the two references will never be equal. While this weakness often only affects program correctness
column7: if the equality is used for a security decision
column8: the unintended comparison result could be leveraged to affect program security.

column2: Automated Recognition Mechanism with Inadequate Detection or Handling of Adversarial Input Perturbations
column4: The product uses an automated mechanism such as machine learning to recognize complex data inputs (e.g. image or audio) as a particular concept or category
column5: but it does not properly detect or handle inputs that have been modified or constructed in a way that causes the mechanism to detect a different
column6: incorrect concept. When techniques such as machine learning are used to automatically classify input streams
column7: and those classifications are used for security-critical decisions
column8: then any mistake in classification can introduce a vulnerability that allows attackers to cause the product to make the wrong security decision. If the automated mechanism is not developed or "trained" with enough input data
column9: then attackers may be able to craft malicious input that intentionally triggers the incorrect classification. Targeted technologies include
column10: but are not necessarily limited to: automated speech recognition automated image recognition For example
column11: an attacker might modify road signs or road surface markings to trick autonomous vehicles into misreading the sign/marking and performing a dangerous action.

column2: Floating Point Comparison with Incorrect Operator
column4: The code performs a comparison such as an equality test between two float (floating point) values
column5: but it uses comparison operators that do not account for the possibility of loss of precision. Numeric calculation using floating point values can generate imprecise results because of rounding errors. As a result
column6: two different calculations might generate numbers that are mathematically equal
column7: but have slightly different bit representations that do not translate to the same mathematically-equal values. As a result
column8: an equality test or other comparison might produce unexpected results. This issue can prevent the product from running reliably. If the relevant code is reachable by an attacker
column9: then this reliability problem might introduce a vulnerability.

column2: Incorrect Comparison Logic Granularity
column4: The product's comparison logic is performed over a series of steps rather than across the entire string in one operation. If there is a comparison logic failure on one of these steps
column5: the operation may be vulnerable to a timing attack that can result in the interception of the process for nefarious purposes. Comparison logic is used to compare a variety of objects including passwords
column6: Message Authentication Codes (MACs)
column7: and responses to verification challenges. When comparison logic is implemented at a finer granularity (e.g.
column8: byte-by-byte comparison) and breaks in the case of a comparison failure
column9: an attacker can exploit this implementation to identify when exactly the failure occurred. With multiple attempts
column10: the attacker may be able to guesses the correct password/response to challenge and elevate their privileges.

column2: Permissive List of Allowed Inputs
column4: The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are explicitly allowed by policy because the inputs are assumed to be safe
column5: but the list is too permissive - that is
column6: it allows an input that is unsafe
column7: leading to resultant weaknesses.

column2: Permissive Cross-domain Policy with Untrusted Domains
column4: The product uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted. A cross-domain policy file ("crossdomain.xml" in Flash and "clientaccesspolicy.xml" in Silverlight) defines a list of domains from which a server is allowed to make cross-domain requests. When making a cross-domain request
column5: the Flash or Silverlight client will first look for the policy file on the target server. If it is found
column6: and the domain hosting the application is explicitly allowed to make requests
column7: the request is made. Therefore
column8: if a cross-domain policy file includes domains that should not be trusted
column10: then the application could be attacked by these untrusted domains. An overly permissive policy file allows many of the same attacks seen in Cross-Site Scripting (CWE-79). Once the user has executed a malicious Flash or Silverlight application
column11: they are vulnerable to a variety of attacks. The attacker could transfer private information
column12: such as cookies that may include session information
column13: from the victim's machine to the attacker. The attacker could send malicious requests to a web site on behalf of the victim
column14: which could be especially dangerous to the site if the victim has administrator privileges to manage that site. In many cases
column15: the attack can be launched without the victim even being aware of it.

column2: Incorrect Regular Expression
column4: The product specifies a regular expression in a way that causes data to be improperly matched or compared. When the regular expression is used in protection mechanisms such as filtering or validation
column5: this may allow an attacker to bypass the intended restrictions on the incoming data.

column2: Overly Restrictive Regular Expression
column4: A regular expression is overly restrictive
column5: which prevents dangerous values from being detected. This weakness is not about regular expression complexity. Rather
column6: it is about a regular expression that does not match all values that are intended. Consider the use of a regexp to identify acceptable values or to spot unwanted terms. An overly restrictive regexp misses some potentially security-relevant values leading to either false positives *or* false negatives
column7: depending on how the regexp is being used within the code. Consider the expression /[0-8]/ where the intention was /[0-9]/. This expression is not "complex" but the value "9" is not matched when maybe the programmer planned to check for it.

column2: Regular Expression without Anchors
column4: The product uses a regular expression to perform neutralization
column5: but the regular expression is not anchored and may allow malicious or malformed data to slip through. When performing tasks such as validating against a set of allowed inputs (allowlist)
column6: data is examined and possibly modified to ensure that it is well-formed and adheres to a list of safe values. If the regular expression is not anchored
column7: malicious or malformed data may be included before or after any string matching the regular expression. The type of malicious data that is allowed will depend on the context of the application and which anchors are omitted from the regular expression.

column2: Object Model Violation: Just One of Equals and Hashcode Defined
column4: The product does not maintain equal hashcodes for equal objects. Java objects are expected to obey a number of invariants related to equality. One of these invariants is that equal objects must have equal hashcodes. In other words
column5: if a.equals(b) == true then a.hashCode() == b.hashCode().

column2: Improper Check or Handling of Exceptional Conditions
column4: The product does not properly anticipate or handle exceptional conditions that rarely occur during normal operation of the product.

column2: Improper Protection Against Voltage and Clock Glitches
column4: The device does not contain or contains incorrectly implemented circuitry or sensors to detect and mitigate voltage and clock glitches and protect sensitive information or software contained on the device. A device might support features such as secure boot which are supplemented with hardware and firmware support. This involves establishing a chain of trust
column5: starting with an immutable root of trust by checking the signature of the next stage (culminating with the OS and runtime software) against a golden value before transferring control. The intermediate stages typically set up the system in a secure state by configuring several access control settings. Similarly
column6: security logic for exercising a debug or testing interface may be implemented in hardware
column7: firmware
column8: or both. A device needs to guard against fault attacks such as voltage glitches and clock glitches that an attacker may employ in an attempt to compromise the system.

column2: Improper Handling of Single Event Upsets
column4: The hardware logic does not effectively handle when single-event upsets (SEUs) occur. Technology trends such as CMOS-transistor down-sizing
column5: use of new materials
column6: and system-on-chip architectures continue to increase the sensitivity of systems to soft errors. These errors are random
column7: and their causes might be internal (e.g.
column9: cosmic radiation). These soft errors are not permanent in nature and cause temporary bit flips known as single-event upsets (SEUs). SEUs are induced errors in circuits caused when charged particles lose energy by ionizing the medium through which they pass
column10: leaving behind a wake of electron-hole pairs that cause temporary failures. If these failures occur in security-sensitive modules in a chip
column11: it might compromise the security guarantees of the chip. For instance
column12: these temporary failures could be bit flips that change the privilege of a regular user to root.

column2: Improper Handling of Faults that Lead to Instruction Skips
column4: The device is missing or incorrectly implements circuitry or sensors that detect and mitigate the skipping of security-critical CPU instructions when they occur. The operating conditions of hardware may change in ways that cause unexpected behavior to occur
column5: including the skipping of security-critical CPU instructions. Generally
column6: this can occur due to electrical disturbances or when the device operates outside of its expected conditions. In practice
column7: application code may contain conditional branches that are security-sensitive (e.g.
column8: accepting or rejecting a user-provided password). These conditional branches are typically implemented by a single conditional branch instruction in the program binary which
column10: may lead to effectively flipping the branch condition - i.e.
column11: causing the wrong security-sensitive branch to be taken. This affects processes such as firmware authentication
column13: and other security-sensitive decision points. Attackers can use fault injection techniques to alter the operating conditions of hardware so that security-critical instructions are skipped more frequently or more reliably than they would in a "natural" setting.

column2: Improper Handling of Hardware Behavior in Exceptionally Cold Environments
column4: A hardware device
column5: or the firmware running on it
column6: is missing or has incorrect protection features to maintain goals of security primitives when the device is cooled below standard operating temperatures. The hardware designer may improperly anticipate hardware behavior when exposed to exceptionally cold conditions. As a result they may introduce a weakness by not accounting for the modified behavior of critical components when in extreme environments. An example of a change in behavior is that power loss won't clear/reset any volatile state when cooled below standard operating temperatures. This may result in a weakness when the starting state of the volatile memory is being relied upon for a security decision. For example
column7: a Physical Unclonable Function (PUF) may be supplied as a security primitive to improve confidentiality
column10: when the PUF is paired with DRAM
column12: or another temperature sensitive entropy source
column13: the system designer may introduce weakness by failing to account for the chosen entropy source's behavior at exceptionally low temperatures. In the case of DRAM and SRAM
column14: when power is cycled at low temperatures
column15: the device will not contain the bitwise biasing caused by inconsistencies in manufacturing and will instead contain the data from previous boot. Should the PUF primitive be used in a cryptographic construction which does not account for full adversary control of PUF seed data
column16: weakness would arise. This weakness does not cover "Cold Boot Attacks" wherein RAM or other external storage is super cooled and read externally by an attacker.

column6: or arguments is not provided in input
column7: or if those parameters are undefined.

column5: but are not.

column2: Improper Handling of Length Parameter Inconsistency
column4: The product parses a formatted message or structure
column5: but it does not handle or incorrectly handles a length field that is inconsistent with the actual length of the associated data. If an attacker can manipulate the length parameter associated with an input such that it is inconsistent with the actual length of the input
column6: this can be leveraged to cause the target application to behave in unexpected
column7: and possibly
column8: malicious ways. One of the possible motives for doing so is to pass in arbitrarily large input to the application. Another possible motivation is the modification of application state by including invalid data for subsequent properties of the application. Such weaknesses commonly lead to attacks such as buffer overflows and execution of arbitrary code.

column2: Improper Handling of Unexpected Data Type

column2: Uncaught Exception
column4: An exception is thrown from a function
column5: but it is not caught. When an exception is not caught
column6: it may cause the program to crash or expose sensitive information.

column2: Uncaught Exception in Servlet
column4: The Servlet does not catch all exceptions
column5: which may reveal sensitive debugging information. When a Servlet throws an exception
column6: the default error response the Servlet container sends back to the user typically includes debugging information. This information is of great value to an attacker. For example
column7: a stack trace might show the attacker a malformed SQL query string
column8: the type of database being used
column9: and the version of the application container. This information enables the attacker to target known vulnerabilities in these components.

column2: Improper Handling of Insufficient Entropy in TRNG
column4: True random number generators (TRNG) generally have a limited source of entropy and therefore can fail or block. The rate at which true random numbers can be generated is limited. It is important that one uses them only when they are needed for security.

column2: Missing Report of Error Condition
column4: The product encounters an error but does not provide a status code or return value to indicate that an error has occurred.

column2: Return of Wrong Status Code
column4: A function or operation returns an incorrect return value or status code that does not indicate an error
column5: but causes the product to modify its behavior based on the incorrect result. This can lead to unpredictable behavior. If the function is used to make security-critical decisions or provide security-critical information
column6: then the wrong status code can cause the product to assume that an action is safe
column7: even when it is not.

column2: Declaration of Throws for Generic Exception
column4: Throwing overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities. Declaring a method to throw Exception or Throwable makes it difficult for callers to perform proper error handling and error recovery. Java's exception mechanism
column5: for example
column6: is set up to make it easy for callers to anticipate what can go wrong and write code to handle each specific exceptional circumstance. Declaring that a method throws a generic form of exception defeats this system.

column2: Improper Check for Unusual or Exceptional Conditions
column4: The product does not check or incorrectly checks for unusual or exceptional conditions that are not expected to occur frequently during day to day operation of the product. The programmer may assume that certain events or conditions will never occur or do not need to be worried about
column5: such as low memory conditions
column6: lack of access to resources due to restrictive permissions
column7: or misbehaving clients or components. However
column8: attackers may intentionally trigger these unusual conditions
column12: or a vulnerability. Note that this entry is not exclusively about the use of exceptions and exception handling
column13: which are mechanisms for both checking and handling unusual or unexpected conditions.

column2: Unchecked Return Value
column4: The product does not check the return value from a method or function
column5: which can prevent it from detecting unexpected states and conditions. Two common programmer assumptions are "this function call can never fail" and "it doesn't matter if this function call fails". If an attacker can force the function to fail or otherwise return a value that is not expected
column6: then the subsequent program logic could lead to a vulnerability
column7: because the product is not in a state that the programmer assumes. For example
column8: if the program calls a function to drop privileges but does not check the return code to ensure that privileges were successfully dropped
column9: then the program will continue to operate with the higher privileges.

column2: Incorrect Check of Function Return Value
column4: The product incorrectly checks a return value from a function
column5: which prevents it from detecting errors or exceptional conditions. Important and common functions will return some value about the success of its actions. This will alert the program whether or not to handle any errors caused by that function.

column2: Improper Check for Dropped Privileges
column4: The product attempts to drop privileges but does not check or incorrectly checks to see if the drop succeeded. If the drop fails
column5: the product will continue to run with the raised privileges
column6: which might provide additional access to unprivileged users.

column2: Improper Validation of Integrity Check Value
column4: The product does not validate or incorrectly validates the integrity check values or "checksums" of a message. This may prevent it from detecting if the data has been modified or corrupted in transmission. Improper validation of checksums before use results in an unnecessary risk that can easily be mitigated. The protocol specification describes the algorithm used for calculating the checksum. It is then a simple matter of implementing the calculation and verifying that the calculated checksum and the received checksum match. Improper verification of the calculated checksum and the received checksum can lead to far greater consequences.

column2: Unchecked Error Condition
column4: [PLANNED FOR DEPRECATION. SEE MAINTENANCE NOTES AND CONSIDER CWE-252
column5: CWE-248
column6: OR CWE-1069.] Ignoring exceptions and other error conditions may allow an attacker to induce unexpected behavior unnoticed.

column2: Unexpected Status Code or Return Value
column4: The product does not properly check when a function or operation returns a value that is legitimate for the function
column5: but is not expected by the product.

column4: A NULL pointer dereference occurs when the application dereferences a pointer that it expects to be valid
column5: but is NULL
column6: typically causing a crash or exit. NULL pointer dereference issues can occur through a number of flaws

column2: Improper Handling of Exceptional Conditions
column4: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles an exceptional condition.

column4: The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment

column6: or associated data. The sensitive information may be valuable information on its own (such as a password)
column7: or it may be useful for launching other
column8: more serious attacks. The error message may be created in different ways: self-generated: the source code explicitly constructs the error message and delivers it externally-generated: the external environment
column10: handles the error and constructs its own message
column11: whose contents are not under direct control by the programmer An attacker may use the contents of error messages to help launch another

column14: this could be used to select the proper number of ".." sequences to navigate to the targeted file. An attack using SQL injection (CWE-89) might not initially succeed

column16: which would expose query logic and possibly even passwords or other sensitive information used within the query.

column2: Self-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: The product identifies an error condition and creates its own diagnostic or error messages that contain sensitive information.

column2: Externally-Generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: The product performs an operation that triggers an external diagnostic or error message that is not directly generated or controlled by the product
column5: such as an error generated by the programming language interpreter that a software application uses. The error can contain sensitive system information.

column4: A command shell error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in the web application code. In many cases
column5: an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause these errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

column2: Servlet Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: A servlet error message indicates that there exists an unhandled exception in your web application code and may provide useful information to an attacker.

column2: Java Runtime Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: In many cases
column5: an attacker can leverage the conditions that cause unhandled exception errors in order to gain unauthorized access to the system.

column2: Server-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
column4: Certain conditions
column5: such as network failure
column6: will cause a server error message to be displayed. While error messages in and of themselves are not dangerous
column7: per se
column8: it is what an attacker can glean from them that might cause eventual problems.

column2: Improper Handling of Insufficient Privileges

column2: Improper Handling of Insufficient Permissions or Privileges

column2: Detection of Error Condition Without Action
column4: The product detects a specific error
column5: but takes no actions to handle the error.

column2: Use of NullPointerException Catch to Detect NULL Pointer Dereference
column4: Catching NullPointerException should not be used as an alternative to programmatic checks to prevent dereferencing a null pointer. Programmers typically catch NullPointerException under three circumstances: The program contains a null pointer dereference. Catching the resulting exception was easier than fixing the underlying problem. The program explicitly throws a NullPointerException to signal an error condition. The code is part of a test harness that supplies unexpected input to the classes under test. Of these three circumstances
column5: only the last is acceptable.

column2: Declaration of Catch for Generic Exception
column4: Catching overly broad exceptions promotes complex error handling code that is more likely to contain security vulnerabilities. Multiple catch blocks can get ugly and repetitive
column5: but "condensing" catch blocks by catching a high-level class like Exception can obscure exceptions that deserve special treatment or that should not be caught at this point in the program. Catching an overly broad exception essentially defeats the purpose of Java's typed exceptions
column6: and can become particularly dangerous if the program grows and begins to throw new types of exceptions. The new exception types will not receive any attention.

column2: Improper Cleanup on Thrown Exception
column4: The product does not clean up its state or incorrectly cleans up its state when an exception is thrown
column5: leading to unexpected state or control flow. Often
column6: when functions or loops become complicated
column7: some level of resource cleanup is needed throughout execution. Exceptions can disturb the flow of the code and prevent the necessary cleanup from happening.

column2: Missing Standardized Error Handling Mechanism
column4: The product does not use a standardized method for handling errors throughout the code
column5: which might introduce inconsistent error handling and resultant weaknesses. If the product handles error messages individually
column6: on a one-by-one basis
column7: this is likely to result in inconsistent error handling. The causes of errors may be lost. Also
column8: detailed information about the causes of an error may be unintentionally returned to the user.

column2: Not Failing Securely ('Failing Open')
column4: When the product encounters an error condition or failure
column5: its design requires it to fall back to a state that is less secure than other options that are available
column6: such as selecting the weakest encryption algorithm or using the most permissive access control restrictions. By entering a less secure state
column7: the product inherits the weaknesses associated with that state
column8: making it easier to compromise. At the least
column9: it causes administrators to have a false sense of security. This weakness typically occurs as a result of wanting to "fail functional" to minimize administration and support costs

column2: Non-exit on Failed Initialization
column4: The product does not exit or otherwise modify its operation when security-relevant errors occur during initialization
column5: such as when a configuration file has a format error or a hardware security module (HSM) cannot be activated
column6: which can cause the product to execute in a less secure fashion than intended by the administrator.

column2: Missing Custom Error Page
column4: The product does not return custom error pages to the user
column5: possibly exposing sensitive information.

column2: J2EE Misconfiguration: Missing Custom Error Page
column4: The default error page of a web application should not display sensitive information about the product. A Web application must define a default error page for 4xx errors (e.g. 404)
column5: 5xx (e.g. 500) errors and catch java.lang.Throwable exceptions to prevent attackers from mining information from the application container's built-in error response. When an attacker explores a web site looking for vulnerabilities
column6: the amount of information that the site provides is crucial to the eventual success or failure of any attempted attacks.

column2: Improper Neutralization
column4: The product does not ensure or incorrectly ensures that structured messages or data are well-formed and that certain security properties are met before being read from an upstream component or sent to a downstream component. If a message is malformed
column5: it may cause the message to be incorrectly interpreted. Neutralization is an abstract term for any technique that ensures that input (and output) conforms with expectations and is "safe." This can be done by: checking that the input/output is already "safe" (e.g. validation) transformation of the input/output to be "safe" using techniques such as filtering
column6: encoding/decoding
column7: escaping/unescaping
column9: or canonicalization preventing the input/output from being directly provided by an attacker (e.g. "indirect selection" that maps externally-provided values to internally-controlled values) preventing the input/output from being processed at all This weakness typically applies in cases where the product prepares a control message that another process must act on
column10: such as a command or query
column11: and malicious input that was intended as data
column12: can enter the control plane instead. However
column13: this weakness also applies to more general cases where there are not always control implications.

column2: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output
column4: The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component
column5: but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result
column6: the intended structure of the message is not preserved. Improper encoding or escaping can allow attackers to change the commands that are sent to another component
column7: inserting malicious commands instead. Most products follow a certain protocol that uses structured messages for communication between components
column8: such as queries or commands. These structured messages can contain raw data interspersed with metadata or control information. For example
column9: "GET /index.html HTTP/1.1" is a structured message containing a command ("GET") with a single argument ("/index.html") and metadata about which protocol version is being used ("HTTP/1.1"). If an application uses attacker-supplied inputs to construct a structured message without properly encoding or escaping
column10: then the attacker could insert special characters that will cause the data to be interpreted as control information or metadata. Consequently
column11: the component that receives the output will perform the wrong operations
column12: or otherwise interpret the data incorrectly.

column2: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs
column4: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes output that is written to logs. This can allow an attacker to forge log entries or inject malicious content into logs. Log forging vulnerabilities occur when: Data enters an application from an untrusted source. The data is written to an application or system log file.

column2: Improper Neutralization of HTTP Headers for Scripting Syntax

column5: such as Flash. An attacker may be able to conduct cross-site scripting and other attacks against users who have these components enabled. If a product does not neutralize user controlled data being placed in the header of an HTTP response coming from the server
column6: the header may contain a script that will get executed in the client's browser context
column7: potentially resulting in a cross site scripting vulnerability or possibly an HTTP response splitting attack. It is important to carefully control data that is being placed both in HTTP response header and in the HTTP response body to ensure that no scripting syntax is present

column2: Inappropriate Encoding for Output Context
column4: The product uses or specifies an encoding when generating output to a downstream component
column5: but the specified encoding is not the same as the encoding that is expected by the downstream component. This weakness can cause the downstream component to use a decoding method that produces different data than what the product intended to send. When the wrong encoding is used - even if closely related - the downstream component could decode the data incorrectly. This can have security consequences when the provided boundaries between control and data are inadvertently broken
column6: because the resulting data could introduce control characters or special elements that were not sent by the product. The resulting data could then be used to bypass protection mechanisms such as input validation
column7: and enable injection attacks. While using output encoding is essential for ensuring that communications between components are accurate
column8: the use of the wrong encoding - even if closely related - could cause the downstream component to misinterpret the output. For example
column9: HTML entity encoding is used for elements in the HTML body of a web page. However
column10: a programmer might use entity encoding when generating output for that is used within an attribute of an HTML tag
column11: which could contain functional Javascript that is not affected by the HTML encoding. While web applications have received the most attention for this problem
column12: this weakness could potentially apply to any type of product that uses a communications stream that could support multiple encodings.

column4: The product receives input from an upstream component
column5: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as control elements or syntactic markers when they are sent to a downstream component. If product does not prevent external control or influence over the inclusion of such special elements

column7: both Unix and Windows interpret the symbol < ("less than") as meaning "read input from a file".

column17: etc. metadata - information about the raw data
column18: such as headers or size Data can be simple or structured. Structured data can be composed of many nested layers
column19: composed of combinations of metadata and raw data

column21: such as: specified quantities such as size
column29: such as the actual size of a file instead of a specified size indexes

column34: i.e. syntactic correctness - compliance with expected syntax lexical token correctness - compliance with rules for what is treated as a token specified or derived type - the actual type of the input (or what the input appears to be) consistency - between individual data elements
column38: e.g. business logic equivalence - ensuring that equivalent inputs are treated the same authenticity
column40: or other attestations about the input
column41: e.g. a cryptographic signature to prove the source of the data Implied or derived properties of data must often be calculated or inferred by the code itself. Errors in deriving properties may be considered a contributing factor to improper input validation. Note that "input validation" has very different meanings to different people
column42: or within different classification schemes. Caution must be used when referencing this CWE entry or mapping to it. For example
column43: some weaknesses might involve inadvertently giving control to an attacker over an input when they should not be able to provide an input at all
column44: but sometimes this is referred to as input validation. Finally
column45: it is important to emphasize that the distinctions between input validation and output escaping are often blurred
column46: and developers must be careful to understand the difference
column47: including how input validation is not always sufficient to prevent vulnerabilities
column48: especially when less stringent data types must be supported
column49: such as free-form text. Consider a SQL injection scenario in which a person's last name is inserted into a query. The name "O'Reilly" would likely pass the validation step since it is a common last name in the English language. However
column50: this valid name cannot be directly inserted into the database because it contains the "'" apostrophe character
column51: which would need to be escaped or otherwise transformed. In this case

These frameworks will automatically check all input against specified criteria and direct execution to error handlers when invalid input is received. The improper use (i.e.

Not using provided input validation frameworks can also hurt the maintainability of code as future developers may not recognize the downstream input validation being used in the place of the validation framework.

column4: The product constructs all or part of a command

Injection problems encompass a wide variety of issues -- all mitigated in very different ways and usually attempted in order to alter the control flow of the process. For this reason
column8: the most effective way to discuss these weaknesses is to note the distinct features that classify them as injection weaknesses. The most important issue to note is that all injection problems share one thing in common -- i.e.

By executing the command

column12: fixed program that is under its own control. It intends to use externally-supplied inputs as arguments to that program. For example

column17: which allows them to execute their own program after nslookup has finished executing. The application accepts an input that it uses to fully select which program to run

Although J2EE applications are not generally susceptible to memory corruption attacks

column2: Failure to Disable Reserved Bits
column4: The reserved bits in a hardware design are not disabled prior to production. Typically
column5: reserved bits are used for future capabilities and should not support any functional logic in the design. However
column6: designers might covertly use these bits to debug or further develop new capabilities in production hardware. Adversaries with access to these bits will write to them in hopes of compromising hardware state. Reserved bits are labeled as such so they can be allocated for a later purpose. They are not to do anything in the current design. However
column7: designers might want to use these bits to debug or control/configure a future capability to help minimize time to market (TTM). If the logic being controlled by these bits is still enabled in production
column8: an adversary could use the logic to induce unwanted/unsupported behavior in the hardware.

column10: or similar components that traditionally have had limited or no update capabilities. In industries such as healthcare
column11: "legacy" devices can be operated for decades. As a US task force report [REF-1197] notes
column12: "the inability to update or replace equipment has both large and small health care delivery organizations struggle with numerous unsupported legacy systems that cannot easily be replaced (hardware
column14: and operating systems) with large numbers of vulnerabilities and few modern countermeasures." While hardware can be prone to this weakness
column15: software systems can also be affected
column16: such as when a third-party driver or library is no longer actively maintained or supported but is still critical for the required functionality.

column2: Firmware Not Updateable
column4: The product does not provide its users with the ability to update or patch its firmware to address any vulnerabilities or weaknesses that may be present. Without the ability to patch or update firmware

column6: or any vulnerabilities that are discovered in the future. This can expose consumers to permanent risk throughout the entire lifetime of the device
column7: which could be years or decades. Some external protective measures and mitigations might be employed to aid in preventing or reducing the risk of malicious attack
column8: but the root weakness cannot be corrected.

column2: Missing Ability to Patch ROM Code
column4: Missing an ability to patch ROM code may leave a System or System-on-Chip (SoC) in a vulnerable state. A System or System-on-Chip (SoC) that implements a boot process utilizing security mechanisms such as Root-of-Trust (RoT) typically starts by executing code from a Read-only-Memory (ROM) component. The code in ROM is immutable
column5: hence any security vulnerabilities discovered in the ROM code can never be fixed for the systems that are already in use. A common weakness is that the ROM does not have the ability to patch if security vulnerabilities are uncovered after the system gets shipped. This leaves the system in a vulnerable state where an adversary can compromise the SoC.

column2: NULL Pointer Dereference

column2: Improper Following of a Certificate's Chain of Trust
column4: The product does not follow
column5: or incorrectly follows
column6: the chain of trust for a certificate back to a trusted root certificate
column7: resulting in incorrect trust of any resource that is associated with that certificate. If a system does not follow the chain of trust of a certificate to a root server
column8: the certificate loses all usefulness as a metric of trust. Essentially
column9: the trust gained from a certificate is derived from a chain of trust -- with a reputable trusted entity at the end of that list. The end user must trust that reputable source
column10: and this reputable source must vouch for the resource in question through the medium of the certificate. In some cases
column11: this trust traverses several entities who vouch for one another. The entity trusted by the end user is at one end of this trust chain
column12: while the certificate-wielding resource is at the other end of the chain. If the user receives a certificate at the end of one of these trust chains and then proceeds to check only that the first link in the chain
column13: no real trust has been derived
column14: since the entire chain must be traversed back to a trusted source to verify the certificate. There are several ways in which the chain of trust might be broken
column15: including but not limited to: Any certificate in the chain is self-signed
column16: unless it the root. Not every intermediate certificate is checked
column17: starting from the original certificate all the way up to the root certificate. An intermediate
column18: CA-signed certificate does not have the expected Basic Constraints or other important extensions. The root certificate has been compromised or authorized to the wrong party.

column2: Missing Critical Step in Authentication
column4: The product implements an authentication technique
column5: but it skips a step that weakens the technique. Authentication techniques should follow the algorithms that define them exactly
column6: otherwise authentication can be bypassed or more easily subjected to brute force attacks.

column2: Missing Cryptographic Step

column5: resulting in weaker encryption than advertised by the algorithm.

column2: Generation of Predictable IV with CBC Mode
column4: The product generates and uses a predictable initialization Vector (IV) with Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) Mode
column5: which causes algorithms to be susceptible to dictionary attacks when they are encrypted under the same key. CBC mode eliminates a weakness of Electronic Code Book (ECB) mode by allowing identical plaintext blocks to be encrypted to different ciphertext blocks. This is possible by the XOR-ing of an IV with the initial plaintext block so that every plaintext block in the chain is XOR'd with a different value before encryption. If IVs are reused
column6: then identical plaintexts would be encrypted to identical ciphertexts. However
column7: even if IVs are not identical but are predictable
column8: then they still break the security of CBC mode against Chosen Plaintext Attacks (CPA).

column2: Improperly Implemented Security Check for Standard
column4: The product does not implement or incorrectly implements one or more security-relevant checks as specified by the design of a standardized algorithm
column5: protocol
column6: or technique.

column2: Undefined Behavior for Input to API
column4: The behavior of this function is undefined unless its control parameter is set to a specific value.

column2: finalize() Method Without super.finalize()

column2: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Sockets
column4: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using sockets. The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case
column5: the product violates the following EJB guideline: "An enterprise bean must not attempt to listen on a socket
column6: accept connections on a socket
column7: or use a socket for multicast." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "The EJB architecture allows an enterprise bean instance to be a network socket client
column8: but it does not allow it to be a network server. Allowing the instance to become a network server would conflict with the basic function of the enterprise bean-- to serve the EJB clients."

column2: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Class Loader
column4: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the class loader. The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case
column5: the product violates the following EJB guideline: "The enterprise bean must not attempt to create a class loader; obtain the current class loader; set the context class loader; set security manager; create a new security manager; stop the JVM; or change the input
column6: output
column7: and error streams." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "These functions are reserved for the EJB container. Allowing the enterprise bean to use these functions could compromise security and decrease the container's ability to properly manage the runtime environment."

column2: J2EE Bad Practices: Non-serializable Object Stored in Session
column4: The product stores a non-serializable object as an HttpSession attribute

column2: Duplicate Key in Associative List (Alist)

column2: Direct Use of Unsafe JNI

column2: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Management of Connections
column4: The J2EE application directly manages connections
column5: instead of using the container's connection management facilities. The J2EE standard forbids the direct management of connections. It requires that applications use the container's resource management facilities to obtain connections to resources. Every major web application container provides pooled database connection management as part of its resource management framework. Duplicating this functionality in an application is difficult and error prone
column6: which is part of the reason it is forbidden under the J2EE standard.

column2: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Sockets
column4: The J2EE application directly uses sockets instead of using framework method calls. The J2EE standard permits the use of sockets only for the purpose of communication with legacy systems when no higher-level protocol is available. Authoring your own communication protocol requires wrestling with difficult security issues. Without significant scrutiny by a security expert
column5: chances are good that a custom communication protocol will suffer from security problems. Many of the same issues apply to a custom implementation of a standard protocol. While there are usually more resources available that address security concerns related to implementing a standard protocol
column6: these resources are also available to attackers.

column2: J2EE Bad Practices: Direct Use of Threads
column4: Thread management in a Web application is forbidden in some circumstances and is always highly error prone. Thread management in a web application is forbidden by the J2EE standard in some circumstances and is always highly error prone. Managing threads is difficult and is likely to interfere in unpredictable ways with the behavior of the application container. Even without interfering with the container
column5: thread management usually leads to bugs that are hard to detect and diagnose like deadlock
column6: race conditions
column7: and other synchronization errors.

column2: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Synchronization Primitives
column4: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using thread synchronization primitives. The Enterprise JavaBeans specification requires that every bean provider follow a set of programming guidelines designed to ensure that the bean will be portable and behave consistently in any EJB container. In this case
column5: the product violates the following EJB guideline: "An enterprise bean must not use thread synchronization primitives to synchronize execution of multiple instances." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "This rule is required to ensure consistent runtime semantics because while some EJB containers may use a single JVM to execute all enterprise bean's instances
column6: others may distribute the instances across multiple JVMs."

column2: EJB Bad Practices: Use of AWT Swing
column4: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using AWT/Swing. In this case
column5: the product violates the following EJB guideline: "An enterprise bean must not use the AWT functionality to attempt to output information to a display
column6: or to input information from a keyboard." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "Most servers do not allow direct interaction between an application program and a keyboard/display attached to the server system."

column2: EJB Bad Practices: Use of Java I/O
column4: The product violates the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification by using the java.io package. In this case
column5: the product violates the following EJB guideline: "An enterprise bean must not use the java.io package to attempt to access files and directories in the file system." The specification justifies this requirement in the following way: "The file system APIs are not well-suited for business components to access data. Business components should use a resource manager API
column6: such as JDBC

column2: J2EE Framework: Saving Unserializable Objects to Disk

column6: session scoped objects
