column10: thus leaving the web application vulnerable to crashes induced by serialization failure. An attacker may be able to mount a denial of service attack by sending enough requests to the server to force the web application to save objects to disk.

column2: Violation of Secure Design Principles
column4: The product violates well-established principles for secure design. This can introduce resultant weaknesses or make it easier for developers to introduce related weaknesses during implementation. Because code is centered around design
column5: it can be resource-intensive to fix design problems.

column2: System-on-Chip (SoC) Using Components without Unique
column4: Not Language-Specific
column5: The System-on-Chip (SoC) does not have unique
column6: immutable identifiers for each of its components. A System-on-Chip (SoC) comprises several components (IP) with varied trust requirements. It is required that each IP is identified uniquely and should distinguish itself from other entities in the SoC without any ambiguity. The unique secured identity is required for various purposes. Most of the time the identity is used to route a transaction or perform certain actions
column7: including resetting
column9: and acting upon or on behalf of something else. There are several variants of this weakness: A "missing" identifier is when the SoC does not define any mechanism to uniquely identify the IP. An "insufficient" identifier might provide some defenses - for example
column10: against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. A "misconfigured" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available but not implemented correctly. An "ignored" identifier occurs when the SoC/IP has not applied any policies or does not act upon the identifier securely.

column2: Dependency on Vulnerable Third-Party Component
column4: The product has a dependency on a third-party component that contains one or more known vulnerabilities. Many products are large enough or complex enough that part of their functionality uses libraries
column5: modules
column6: or other intellectual property developed by third parties who are not the product creator. For example
column7: even an entire operating system might be from a third-party supplier in some hardware products. Whether open or closed source
column8: these components may contain publicly known vulnerabilities that could be exploited by adversaries to compromise the product.

column2: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
column4: The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required
column5: which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses. New weaknesses can be exposed because running with extra privileges
column6: such as root or Administrator
column7: can disable the normal security checks being performed by the operating system or surrounding environment. Other pre-existing weaknesses can turn into security vulnerabilities if they occur while operating at raised privileges. Privilege management functions can behave in some less-than-obvious ways
column8: and they have different quirks on different platforms. These inconsistencies are particularly pronounced if you are transitioning from one non-root user to another. Signal handlers and spawned processes run at the privilege of the owning process
column9: so if a process is running as root when a signal fires or a sub-process is executed
column10: the signal handler or sub-process will operate with root privileges.

column2: Not Failing Securely ('Failing Open')
column4: When the product encounters an error condition or failure
column5: its design requires it to fall back to a state that is less secure than other options that are available
column6: such as selecting the weakest encryption algorithm or using the most permissive access control restrictions. By entering a less secure state
column7: the product inherits the weaknesses associated with that state
column8: making it easier to compromise. At the least
column9: it causes administrators to have a false sense of security. This weakness typically occurs as a result of wanting to "fail functional" to minimize administration and support costs

column2: Non-exit on Failed Initialization

column5: such as when a configuration file has a format error or a hardware security module (HSM) cannot be activated
column6: which can cause the product to execute in a less secure fashion than intended by the administrator.

column2: Unnecessary Complexity in Protection Mechanism (Not Using 'Economy of Mechanism')
column4: The product uses a more complex mechanism than necessary
column5: which could lead to resultant weaknesses when the mechanism is not correctly understood
column6: modeled
column7: configured
column9: or used. Security mechanisms should be as simple as possible. Complex security mechanisms may engender partial implementations and compatibility problems
column10: with resulting mismatches in assumptions and implemented security. A corollary of this principle is that data specifications should be as simple as possible
column11: because complex data specifications result in complex validation code. Complex tasks and systems may also need to be guarded by complex security checks
column12: so simple systems should be preferred.

column2: Not Using Complete Mediation
column4: The product does not perform access checks on a resource every time the resource is accessed by an entity
column5: which can create resultant weaknesses if that entity's rights or privileges change over time.

column2: Improper Protection of Alternate Path
column4: The product does not sufficiently protect all possible paths that a user can take to access restricted functionality or resources.

column4: The web application does not adequately enforce appropriate authorization on all restricted URLs
column5: scripts
column6: or files. Web applications susceptible to direct request attacks often make the false assumption that such resources can only be reached through a given navigation path and so only apply authorization at certain points in the path.

column2: Improper Isolation or Compartmentalization
column4: The product does not properly compartmentalize or isolate functionality
column5: processes
column6: or resources that require different privilege levels
column7: rights
column8: or permissions. When a weakness occurs in functionality that is accessible by lower-privileged users

column2: Improper Isolation of Shared Resources on System-on-a-Chip (SoC)
column4: The System-On-a-Chip (SoC) does not properly isolate shared resources between trusted and untrusted agents. A System-On-a-Chip (SoC) has a lot of functionality
column5: but it may have a limited number of pins or pads. A pin can only perform one function at a time. However
column6: it can be configured to perform multiple different functions. This technique is called pin multiplexing. Similarly
column7: several resources on the chip may be shared to multiplex and support different features or functions. When such resources are shared between trusted and untrusted agents
column8: untrusted agents may be able to access the assets intended to be accessed only by the trusted agents.

column2: Non-Transparent Sharing of Microarchitectural Resources
column4: Hardware structures shared across execution contexts (e.g.
column5: caches and branch predictors) can violate the expected architecture isolation between contexts. Modern processors use techniques such as out-of-order execution
column6: speculation
column7: prefetching
column9: and caching to increase performance. Details about the implementation of these techniques are hidden from the programmer's view. This is problematic when the hardware implementation of these techniques results in resources being shared across supposedly isolated contexts. Contention for shared resources between different contexts opens covert channels that allow malicious programs executing in one context to recover information from another context. Some examples of shared micro-architectural resources that have been used to leak information between contexts are caches
column11: and load or store buffers. Speculative and out-of-order execution provides an attacker with increased control over which data is leaked through the covert channel. If the extent of resource sharing between contexts in the design microarchitecture is undocumented
column12: it is extremely difficult to ensure system assets are protected against disclosure.

column2: Improper Isolation of Shared Resources in Network On Chip (NoC)
column4: The Network On Chip (NoC) does not isolate or incorrectly isolates its on-chip-fabric and internal resources such that they are shared between trusted and untrusted agents
column5: creating timing channels. Typically
column6: network on chips (NoC) have many internal resources that are shared between packets from different trust domains. These resources include internal buffers
column7: crossbars and switches
column9: and channels. The sharing of resources causes contention and introduces interference between differently trusted domains
column10: which poses a security threat via a timing channel
column11: allowing attackers to infer data that belongs to a trusted agent. This may also result in introducing network interference
column12: resulting in degraded throughput and latency.

column2: Reliance on a Single Factor in a Security Decision
column4: A protection mechanism relies exclusively
column5: or to a large extent

column5: it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak
column6: reused
column7: and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes
column8: a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason

column2: Use of Password System for Primary Authentication
column4: The use of password systems as the primary means of authentication may be subject to several flaws or shortcomings
column5: each reducing the effectiveness of the mechanism.

column2: Insufficient Psychological Acceptability
column4: The product has a protection mechanism that is too difficult or inconvenient to use
column5: encouraging non-malicious users to disable or bypass the mechanism
column6: whether by accident or on purpose.

Note that obscurity can be one small part of defense in depth

This introduces resultant weaknesses or prevents it from operating at a level of security that is desired by the administrator. column5: then protecting the product from outside threats - including the product's developer - can become impossible. For example
column6: a hard-coded account name and password cannot be changed by the administrator

column4: The product contains hard-coded credentials

column6: which it uses for its own inbound authentication

column8: or encryption of internal data. Hard-coded credentials typically create a significant hole that allows an attacker to bypass the authentication that has been configured by the product administrator. This hole might be difficult for the system administrator to detect. Even if detected
column9: it can be difficult to fix
column10: so the administrator may be forced into disabling the product entirely. There are two main variations: Inbound: the product contains an authentication mechanism that checks the input credentials against a hard-coded set of credentials. Outbound: the product connects to another system or component
column11: and it contains hard-coded credentials for connecting to that component. In the Inbound variant
column12: a default administration account is created
column13: and a simple password is hard-coded into the product and associated with that account. This hard-coded password is the same for each installation of the product
column14: and it usually cannot be changed or disabled by system administrators without manually modifying the program
column15: or otherwise patching the product. If the password is ever discovered or published (a common occurrence on the Internet)
column16: then anybody with knowledge of this password can access the product. Finally
column17: since all installations of the product will have the same password
column19: this enables massive attacks such as worms to take place. The Outbound variant applies to front-end systems that authenticate with a back-end service. The back-end service may require a fixed password which can be easily discovered. The programmer may simply hard-code those back-end credentials into the front-end product. Any user of that program may be able to extract the password. Client-side systems with hard-coded passwords pose even more of a threat
column20: since the extraction of a password from a binary is usually very simple.

The back-end service may require a fixed password which can be easily discovered. The programmer may simply hard-code those back-end credentials into the front-end product. Any user of that program may be able to extract the password. Client-side systems with hard-coded passwords pose even more of a threat

column2: Missing Report of Error Condition

column2: Expected Behavior Violation
column4: A feature

column2: UI Discrepancy for Security Feature

column9: if the UI is used to monitor the security state of a system or network
column10: then omitting or obscuring an important indicator could prevent the user from detecting and reacting to a security-critical event. UI misrepresentation can take many forms: Incorrect indicator: incorrect information is displayed
column11: which prevents the user from understanding the true state of the product or the environment the product is monitoring
column12: especially of potentially-dangerous conditions or operations. This can be broken down into several different subtypes. Overlay: an area of the display is intended to give critical information
column13: but another process can modify the display by overlaying another element on top of it. The user is not interacting with the expected portion of the user interface. This is the problem that enables clickjacking attacks
column14: although many other types of attacks exist that involve overlay. Icon manipulation: the wrong icon
column16: can be influenced (such as making a dangerous .EXE executable look like a harmless .GIF) Timing: the product is performing a state transition or context switch that is presented to the user with an indicator
column17: but a race condition can cause the wrong indicator to be used before the product has fully switched context. The race window could be extended indefinitely if the attacker can trigger an error. Visual truncation: important information could be truncated from the display
column18: such as a long filename with a dangerous extension that is not displayed in the GUI because the malicious portion is truncated. The use of excessive whitespace can also cause truncation
column19: or place the potentially-dangerous indicator outside of the user's field of view (e.g. "filename.txt .exe"). A different type of truncation can occur when a portion of the information is removed due to reasons other than length
column20: such as the accidental insertion of an end-of-input marker in the middle of an input
column21: such as a NUL byte in a C-style string. Visual distinction: visual information might be presented in a way that makes it difficult for the user to quickly and correctly distinguish between critical and unimportant segments of the display. Homographs: letters from different character sets
column23: or languages can appear very similar (i.e. may be visually equivalent) in a way that causes the human user to misread the text (for example
column24: to conduct phishing attacks to trick a user into visiting a malicious web site with a visually-similar name as a trusted site). This can be regarded as a type of visual distinction issue.

column2: Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User
column4: The product displays information or identifiers to a user
column5: but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs)
column6: which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended
column7: insecure action. Some glyphs
column9: or icons can be semantically distinct to a program
column10: while appearing very similar or identical to a human user. These are referred to as homoglyphs. For example
column11: the lowercase "l" (ell) and uppercase "I" (eye) have different character codes
column12: but these characters can be displayed in exactly the same way to a user
column13: depending on the font. This can also occur between different character sets. For example
column14: the Latin capital letter "A" and the Greek capital letter "" (Alpha) are treated as distinct by programs
column15: but may be displayed in exactly the same way to a user. Accent marks may also cause letters to appear very similar
column16: such as the Latin capital letter grave mark "?" and its equivalent "?" with the acute accent. Adversaries can exploit this visual similarity for attacks such as phishing
column17: e.g. by providing a link to an attacker-controlled hostname that looks like a hostname that the victim trusts. In a different use of homoglyphs
column18: an adversary may create a back door username that is visually similar to the username of a regular user
column19: which then makes it more difficult for a system administrator to detect the malicious username while reviewing logs.

column2: Embedded Malicious Code
column4: The product contains code that appears to be malicious in nature. Malicious flaws have acquired colorful names
column5: including Trojan horse
column6: trapdoor
column7: timebomb
column8: and logic-bomb. A developer might insert malicious code with the intent to subvert the security of a product or its host system at some time in the future. It generally refers to a program that performs a useful service but exploits rights of the program's user in a way the user does not intend.

column2: Trojan Horse
column4: The product appears to contain benign or useful functionality
column5: but it also contains code that is hidden from normal operation that violates the intended security policy of the user or the system administrator.

column2: Non-Replicating Malicious Code
column4: Non-replicating malicious code only resides on the target system or product that is attacked; it does not attempt to spread to other systems.

column2: Replicating Malicious Code (Virus or Worm)
column4: Replicating malicious code
column5: including viruses and worms
column6: will attempt to attack other systems once it has successfully compromised the target system or the product.

column2: Trapdoor
column4: A trapdoor is a hidden piece of code that responds to a special input
column5: allowing its user access to resources without passing through the normal security enforcement mechanism.

column2: Logic/Time Bomb
column4: The product contains code that is designed to disrupt the legitimate operation of the product (or its environment) when a certain time passes
column5: or when a certain logical condition is met. When the time bomb or logic bomb is detonated
column6: it may perform a denial of service such as crashing the system
column7: deleting critical data
column8: or degrading system response time. This bomb might be placed within either a replicating or non-replicating Trojan horse.

column2: Spyware
column4: The product collects personally identifiable information about a human user or the user's activities
column5: but the product accesses this information using other resources besides itself
column6: and it does not require that user's explicit approval or direct input into the product. "Spyware" is a commonly used term with many definitions and interpretations. In general
column7: it is meant to refer to products that collect information or install functionality that human users might not allow if they were fully aware of the actions being taken by the software. For example
column8: a user might expect that tax software would collect a social security number and include it when filing a tax return
column9: but that same user would not expect gaming software to obtain the social security number from that tax software's data.

column2: Reliance on Undefined
column4: or Implementation-Defined Behavior
column6: The product uses an API function
column7: data structure
column8: or other entity in a way that relies on properties that are not always guaranteed to hold for that entity. This can lead to resultant weaknesses when the required properties change
column9: such as when the product is ported to a different platform or if an interaction error (CWE-435) occurs.

column2: Insecure Automated Optimizations
column4: The product uses a mechanism that automatically optimizes code
column5: e.g. to improve a characteristic such as performance
column6: but the optimizations can have an unintended side effect that might violate an intended security assumption.

column2: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code
column4: The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software
column5: but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

column2: Reliance on Machine-Dependent Data Representation
column4: The code uses a data representation that relies on low-level data representation or constructs that may vary across different processors
column5: physical machines
column6: OSes
column7: or other physical components. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain and/or port the product
column8: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Use of Platform-Dependent Third Party Components
column4: The product relies on third-party components that do not provide equivalent functionality across all desirable platforms. This issue makes it more difficult to maintain the product
column5: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Insufficient Encapsulation of Machine-Dependent Functionality
column4: The product or code uses machine-dependent functionality
column5: but it does not sufficiently encapsulate or isolate this functionality from the rest of the code. This issue makes it more difficult to port or maintain the product
column6: which indirectly affects security by making it more difficult or time-consuming to find and/or fix vulnerabilities. It also might make it easier to introduce vulnerabilities.

column2: Use of Incorrect Byte Ordering
column4: The product receives input from an upstream component
column5: but it does not account for byte ordering (e.g. big-endian and little-endian) when processing the input
column6: causing an incorrect number or value to be used.

column2: Use of Function with Inconsistent Implementations
column4: The code uses a function that has inconsistent implementations across operating systems and versions. The use of inconsistent implementations can cause changes in behavior when the code is ported or built under a different environment than the programmer expects
column5: which can lead to security problems in some cases. The implementation of many functions varies by platform
column6: and at times
column7: even by different versions of the same platform. Implementation differences can include: Slight differences in the way parameters are interpreted leading to inconsistent results. Some implementations of the function carry significant security risks. The function might not be defined on all platforms. The function might change which return codes it can provide
column8: or change the meaning of its return codes.

column2: Call to Non-ubiquitous API
column4: The product uses an API function that does not exist on all versions of the target platform. This could cause portability problems or inconsistencies that allow denial of service or other consequences. Some functions that offer security features supported by the OS are not available on all versions of the OS in common use. Likewise
column5: functions are often deprecated or made obsolete for security reasons and should not be used.

column2: Attempt to Access Child of a Non-structure Pointer
column4: Casting a non-structure type to a structure type and accessing a field can lead to memory access errors or data corruption.
